News}} BD has also donated millions to [[Fairleigh Dickinson University]] (of which BD co-founder Dickinson was a benefactor and namesake), in support of the Henry P. Becton School of Nursing and Allied Health (named for the son of BD's co-founder, also a BD executive), along with other FDU programs.{{cite web|url=http://www.northjersey.com/news/business/becton-dickinson-co-donates-1-million-to-fairleigh-dickinson-university-1.1034981|title=Becton, Dickinson & Co. donates $1 million to Fairleigh Dickinson University}} ===Environmental track record=== As of February 2010, BD was ranked 18th in the EPA Fortune 500 List of Green Power Purchasers.{{cite web|url=http://www.epa.gov/greenpower/toplists/fortune500.htm|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20080511194914/http://epa.gov/greenpower/toplists/fortune500.htm|dead-url=yes|archive-date=2008-05-11|title=Green Power Purchasers Fortune 500 List}} BD was also listed among the top 100 companies in [[Newsweek|Newsweek's]] 2009 Green Rankings{{cite web|url=http://greenrankings.newsweek.com/top500/page:5|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20090924232845/http://greenrankings.newsweek.com/top500/page%3A5|dead-url=yes|archive-date=2009-09-24|title=Newsweek, Greenest Big Companies in America – The 2009 List|df=}} ranking of the 500 largest American corporations based on environmental performance, policies, and reputation. BD placed third in the health care sector and 83rd overall.{{cite web|url=http://greenrankings.newsweek.com/companies/view/becton-dickinson|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20090926082732/http://greenrankings.newsweek.com/companies/view/becton-dickinson|dead-url=yes|archive-date=2009-09-26|title=Newsweek, Green Ranking 2009 - Becton Dickinson|df=}} In addition, BD has been a component of the [[Dow Jones Sustainability Indices|Dow Jones Sustainability World Index]] and the Dow Jones Sustainability North America Index for the four and five consecutive years, respectively.{{cite web|url=http://www.sustainability-index.com/djsi_protected/djsi_world/components/SAM_DJSIWorld_Components.pdf|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20080704183929/http://www.sustainability-index.com/djsi_protected/djsi_world/components/SAM_DJSIWorld_Components.pdf|dead-url=yes|archive-date=2008-07-04|title=Dow Jones Sustainability Indexes}}{{cite web|url=http://www.bd.com/contentmanager/b_article.asp?Item_ID=24179&ContentType_ID=1&BusinessCode=20001&d=BD+Worldwide&s=&dTitle=&dc=&dcTitle=|title=BD Press Release}} ===2007 Discardit II incident in Poland=== In mid-2007, the firm's Discardit II series of syringes numbered 0607186 was withdrawn from hospitals and other medical services around [[Poland]], about half a year after the discovery of remains of dark dust in some syringes, which were alleged to have been from this series.{{cite news | first=Leszek | last=Kraskowski | pages= | language = Polish| title= For over half a year, hospitals used tainted syringes | date=2007-08-01 | publisher=Dziennik Online |url= http://www.dziennik.pl/Default.aspx?TabId=96&ShowArticleId=54999 | access-date=2007-08-03}} The newspaper Dziennik Online claimed that other series such as 06022444, 0603266, and 0607297 were also suspected of being contaminated. BD recalled and tested the syringes in question, and revealed sterile particulates in 0.013 percent of the products.{{cite news|url=https://www.reuters.com/article/companyNewsAndPR/idUSN0640879120070806|title=Reuters: Becton Dickinson expands syringe recall in Poland | date=2007-08-06}} Legal proceedings related to the incident started in December 2006. According to an article published in Dziennik on Monday, 21 April 2008, the prosecutor's office in Lublin discontinued the inquiry, because the disposable syringes were not dangerous. ===2010 Q-Syte Luer and IV Catheter partial recall=== In February 2010 BD announced a voluntary product recall of certain lots of BD Q-Syte Luer Access Devices and BD Nexiva Closed IV Catheter Systems. BD stated that the use of the affected devices may cause an air embolism or leakage of blood and/or therapy, which may result in serious injury or death. The approximately 2.8 million BD Q-Syte and 2.9 million BD Nexiva units containing 5 million BD Q-Syte devices that were recalled were distributed in the United States, Asia, Canada, Europe, Mexico, the Middle East, South Africa, and South America. The recall was initiated on Oct. 28, 2009 after BD received complaints of problems due to air entry through a part of the device. BD stated that the cause of the problem was manufacturing deviation and claimed that it corrected the problem. BD announced that it notified customers about the recall by letter and has been working with the U.S. [[Food and Drug Administration]] and worldwide health agencies to coordinate recall activities.{{cite news|url= https://www.reuters.com/article/idUSN0815057720100208|title=Reuters: Becton Dickinson recalls intravenous devices | date=2010-02-08}}{{cite web|url=http://www.bd.com/contentmanager/b_article.asp?Item_ID=24486&ContentType_ID=1&BusinessCode=20001&d=BD+Worldwide&s=&dTitle=&dc=&dcTitle=|title=BD Press Release}} === Health and safety issues === In April 2016, the Occupational Safety and Health and Administration fined BD $112,700 for safety violations. They found repeat and serious violations of health and safety law that had resulted in two employees having partial finger amputations.{{cite web|url=https://www.osha.gov/pls/oshaweb/owadisp.show_document?p_table=NEWS_RELEASES&p_id=31062|title=OSHA finds dozen violations at Becton, Dickinson and Co. in Holdrege after two workers suffer finger amputations|last=|first=|date=April 12, 2016|website=|publisher=OSHA|access-date=April 18, 2016}} ==See also== {{Portal|New Jersey|Companies|Companies}} * [[Becton, Dickinson and Company headquarters]] * [[List of biotech and pharmaceutical companies in the New York metropolitan area]] ==References== {{Reflist|2}} ==External links== *[http://www.bd.com/en-us U.S. official website] *[http://www.bbb.org/new-jersey/business-reviews/news-publications-trade-association-etc/bd-in-franklin-lakes-nj-90083325 BD - Better Business Bureau (BBB) Review] {{Finance links | name = Becton Dickinson | symbol = BDX | sec_cik = BDX | yahoo = BDX | google = BDX}} [[Category:Companies listed on the New York Stock Exchange]] [[Category:Medical technology companies of the United States]] [[Category:Companies based in Bergen County, New Jersey]] [[Category:Health care companies established in 1897]] [[Category:Franklin Lakes, New Jersey]] [[Category:Life sciences industry]] [[Category:Technology companies established in 1897]]

{{Infobox Company | industry = Software | location = [[Novato, California]], U.S. | founded = By 1984 | defunct = 1987 | fate = Merged into [[Symantec]] | products = Project management software | brands = Time Line, Timeline }} '''Breakthrough Software''' was a software company based in [[Novato, California]]. Breakthrough developed and sold the Time Line [[project management software]] for [[PC DOS]] computers, releasing the first version in 1984,<ref>[https://books.google.com/books?id=0OsESSRYEc0C&pg=PA86&lpg=PA86&dq=breakthrough+software+novato&source=bl&ots=vjhL2SbGxM&sig=ro61ifcYPRipcILjp1wTUz0gunY&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwj9sOnz_LLOAhXD64MKHbmsAQsQ6AEIPzAH#v=onepage&q=breakthrough%20software%20novato&f=false Breakthrough offers project management software for IBM micro]. ''Computerworld'', 3 Sept 1984.</ref> and version 2.0 in July, 1985.<ref name=hb>Hank Bannister. [https://books.google.com/books?id=my8EAAAAMBAJ&lpg=PA5&ots=bo2Bxcxh-C&dq=breakthrough%20software%20novato&pg=PA1#v=onepage&q=breakthrough%20software%20novato&f=false Project Software Demand Growing]. ''InfoWorld'', Jan 27, 1986. page 5.</ref> Company staff in the 1980s included president William Lohse (1984-1985),<ref>[https://books.google.com/books?id=EFea26Iy2kQC&lpg=RA1-PA57&ots=AAR-9vRa5R&dq=breakthrough%20software%20novato&pg=RA1-PA57#v=onepage&q=breakthrough%20software%20novato&f=false Vendors search for next big win]. ''Computerworld'', Mar 25, 1985. page 57.</ref> COO and CEO Victoria Lohse<ref name=vl>[https://books.google.com/books?id=pDwEAAAAMBAJ&lpg=PA31&ots=pG_WWPXyrR&dq=Victoria%20Lohse%20Breakthrough&pg=PA31#v=onepage&q=Victoria%20Lohse%20Breakthrough&f=false Issco agrees to buy maker of Time Line]. ''InfoWorld'', 13 Oct 1986.</ref> and president Andrew Layman starting in 1986.<ref name=hb/>
The product was slightly renamed to Timeline by October, 1986.<ref name=hb/>
Negotiations to merge Breakthrough into Integrated Software Systems Corp. (ISSCO) reached an agreement in principle in October, 1986<ref name=vl/> but broke down soon afterwards when [[Computer Associates]], developer of a different project management program, announced an agreement to acquire ISSCO.<ref>Rachel Parker. [https://books.google.com/books?id=bDwEAAAAMBAJ&lpg=PA16&dq=breakthrough%20software%20novato&pg=PA16#v=onepage&q=breakthrough%20software%20novato&f=false Breakthrough to Withdraw from Merge Plans with ISSCO]. ''InfoWorld'', 15 Dec 1986.</ref>
Breakthrough was acquired by [[Symantec]] in 1987. Symantec continued to release versions of Timeline until at least version 6.0 in 1994.<ref>William Brandel. [https://books.google.com/books?id=j7EPRo-7juEC&lpg=PA30&ots=uM7gz7Gfqg&dq=last%20version%20of%20Timeline%20software%20Symantec&pg=PA30#v=onepage&q=last%20version%20of%20Timeline%20software%20Symantec&f=false Symantec to purchase rival]. ''Computerworld''. 11 April 1994. page 30.</ref>

'''CSR Centre''' is a [[Corporate social responsibility]] focused [[Non-governmental organization]] based in [[Bangladesh]]. Founded in September 2007 by former Bangladeshi diplomat [[Farooq Sobhan]], who currently serves as the Chairman of the Board of Trustees<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.csrcentre-bd.org/index.php?option=com_content&view=article&id=71&Itemid=84|title=Board of Trustees|last=Administrator|website=www.csrcentre-bd.org|language=en-gb|access-date=2018-06-04}}</ref>, CSR Centre is a source of information, resources, and advisory services for sustainable business practices in Bangladesh<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.thedailystar.net/news-detail-2834|title=CSR Centre launched to up stakeholders' benefits|date=2007-09-06|work=The Daily Star|access-date=2018-06-04|language=en}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.thedailystar.net/news-detail-1827|title=Trust to set up CSR centre formed|date=2007-08-29|work=The Daily Star|access-date=2018-06-04|language=en}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.export.gov/article?id=Bangladesh-Responsible-Business-Conduct|title=Bangladesh - 8-Responsible Business Conduct {{!}} export.gov|website=www.export.gov|language=en|access-date=2018-06-04}}</ref>.
The organization is currently headed by Shahamin Zaman, who serves as the Chief Executive Officer, an industry professional who also serves as the Executive Director for the [[United Nations Global Compact]] Bangladesh Network<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.unglobalcompact.org/engage-locally/asia/bangladesh|title=United Nations Global Compact Bangladesh Local Network website.|last=|first=|date=|access-date=4 June 2018}}</ref>, launched in collaboration by CSR Centre, the Bangladesh Enterprise Institute, and [[United Nations Development Programme]]<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://bei-bd.org/focus_area/corporate-social-responsibility-csr/|title=Corporate Social Responsibility|date=2015-03-22|work=Bangladesh Enterprise Institute|access-date=2018-06-04|language=en-US}}</ref>. The organization frequently partners with various governmental<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.dhakatribune.com/uncategorized/2014/10/23/csr-guideline-on-cards-to-expedite-projects|title=CSR guideline on cards to expedite projects|date=2014-10-23|work=Dhaka Tribune|access-date=2018-06-04|language=en-US}}</ref>, local<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.dhakatribune.com/bangladesh/dhaka/2017/12/04/speakers-residual-structure-promote-csr-sdgs/|title=Speakers for a residual structure to promote CSR through the SDGs|date=2017-12-03|work=Dhaka Tribune|access-date=2018-06-04|language=en-US}}</ref>, and international organizations<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://nccib.com/responsible-business-through-partnerships-csr/|title=Responsible Business through Partnerships & CSR – NCCI|website=nccib.com|language=en-US|access-date=2018-06-04}}</ref> on CSR related initiatives across Bangladesh.
Since 2017, the CSR Centre has been working closely with the [[Ministry of Planning (Bangladesh)]] to develop a comprehensive national CSR guideline for local businesses<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.dhakatribune.com/uncategorized/2016/01/23/planning-ministry-for-common-csr-guidelines|title=Planning Ministry for common CSR guidelines|date=2016-01-23|work=Dhaka Tribune|access-date=2018-06-04|language=en-US}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.thedailystar.net/business/new-csr-guideline-cards-1442704|title=New CSR guideline on cards|date=2017-08-03|work=The Daily Star|access-date=2018-06-04|language=en}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|url=http://bangladesh.um.dk/en/about-us/news/newsdisplaypage/?newsid=b38b3190-2e37-45a5-a856-9374ee94d9f3|title=Launch of Report on CSR in Bangladesh 2014 - Sustainability for a Better Future|last=Bangladesh|first=Denmark in|work=Denmark in Bangladesh|access-date=2018-06-04|language=en}}</ref>.

[[Canada]] was the second nation in the world to formally organize its accounting profession, after the [[United Kingdom]], but it occurred in a fragmented manner by both locality and specialty. It would only begin to experience significant consolidation from 2012 onwards.
After some controversy in the first part of the 20th Century, it has been generally agreed that regulation of the '''Canadian accounting profession''' falls within provincial jurisdiction over matters of a local and private nature,<ref group="nb">held ''[[obiter]]'' by the [[Supreme Court of Canada]] in {{cite CanLII|litigants=Reference Re Securities Act|link=Reference Re Securities Act|year=2011|court=scc|num=6|pinpoint=par. 34|parallelcite=[2011] 3 SCR 837|date=2011-12-22}}</ref> as well as under the provincial education power with respect to training for achieving such professional qualifications.{{sfn|Richardson|Kilfoyle|2012|p=9}}
==Timeline of Canadian accounting bodies== {{Simple Horizontal timeline

|row2=timeline |row2-height=3.5em |row2-texttop=1em |row2-bordertop=solid 0.1em black; |row2-1-to=1918 |row2-1-text= |row2-1-colour= |row2-2-text=[[Certified Public Accountant]] |row2-2-to=1967 |row2-2-colour=#E5E4E2

==Creation of different specialties== ===Chartered accountants=== ====Organization of provincial societies==== Demand for trained accountants arose as early as the 1840s, when the first Canadian professional accounting firms were organized in [[Toronto]] and [[Montreal]].{{sfn|Richardson|1996|p=89}}
The Association of Accountants in Montreal was organized as the first accounting organization in North America in 1879<ref name="5Things">{{cite web |url= http://www.canadian-accountant.com/content/business/canada-150-five-things-you-didn-t-know-about-the-history-of-accounting-in-canada|title= Canada 150: Five things you didn't know about the history of accounting in Canada|last= Ellis|first= Colin|date= June 30, 2017|publisher= Canadian Accountant}}</ref> (and only the fifth such organization in the world),{{sfn|Richardson|1993b|p=559}} and was incorporated by an Act of the [[Legislative Assembly of Quebec]].<ref group="na">{{Cite canlaw|short title = An Act to incorporate the Association of Accountants in Montreal|abbr = S.Q.|year = 1880|chapter = 88|link = https://books.google.com/books?id=PoMwAQAAMAAJ&lpg=PA265&ots=WFl3OaPENZ&pg=PA404#v=onepage&f=false}}</ref> Ontario would follow several weeks later with the formation of the Institute of Accountants and Adjusters of Ontario,<ref name="5Things"/> which was later incorporated as the Institute of Accountants of Ontario in 1883 under the direction of E.R.C. Clarkson, one of the founding members of Clarkson Gordon & Co, and a key member in the growth of the accounting and insolvency consulting industry in Canada. E.R.C. Further acted as a frequent advisor to the Canadian Senate in regard to the banking committee.<ref group="na">{{Cite canlaw|short title = An Act to Incorporate the Institute of Accountants of Ontario|abbr = S.O.|year = 1883|chapter = 62|link = https://archive.org/stream/statutesofprovin1883onta#page/494/mode/2up}}</ref><ref>Mackenzie, The Clarkson Gordon Story 1864-1989, (University of Toronto Press, 1989) 7</ref> It was reconstituted as the Institute of Chartered Accountants of Ontario ("ICAO") in 1911.<ref name="CA1911" group="na"/>
As the AAM tended to have an [[anglophone]] membership, the Institute of Accountants and Auditors of the Province of Quebec was later incorporated to service growing demand within Quebec's [[francophone]] population.{{sfn|Richardson|1996|p=89}}<ref group="na">{{Cite canlaw|short title = Loi constituant en corporation l'Institut des comptables et auditeurs de la Province de Québec|abbr = S.Q.|year = 1912-13|chapter = 94|link = https://www.bibliotheque.assnat.qc.ca/DepotNumerique_v2/AffichageFichier.aspx?idf=128059}}</ref> In 1919, the AAM began to offer admission for members of the IAAPQ.{{sfn|Richardson|1993b|p=575}}
Manitoba would be the third province to organize its chartered accountants, and it would later be instrumental in organizing similar professional bodies in British Columbia, Alberta and Saskatchewan.{{sfn|Richardson|1993b|pp=564-565}}
Nova Scotia organized in 1900,<ref group="na">{{Cite canlaw|short title =An Act to incorporate the Institute of Chartered Accountants of Nova Scotia|abbr =S.N.S.|year =1900|chapter =154|link=http://0-nsleg-edeposit.gov.ns.ca.legcat.gov.ns.ca/deposit/Statutes/1900.pdf}}</ref> followed by New Brunswick in 1916<ref group="na">S.N.B. 1916, c. 53</ref> and Prince Edward Island in 1921.<ref group="na">S.P.E.I. 1921, c. 25</ref> The latter two bodies were organized in an irregular manner compared to those of other provinces,{{efn|the New Brunswick Institute conferred membership on anyone who was a member of any incorporated society of accountants in the [[British Empire]] or the [[United States]],{{sfn|Richardson|1993b|pp=572-573}} and the PEI Institute was formed without the knowledge or consent of existing CAs.{{sfn|Richardson|1993b|p=578}}}} which resulted in their qualifications not being recognized by Nova Scotia until 1925,{{sfn|Richardson|1993b|p=581}} and by Quebec and Ontario until 1926.{{sfn|Richardson|1993b|p=582}}
Outside Canada, the [[Dominion of Newfoundland]] incorporated the Institute of Accountants in 1905,<ref group="na">{{Cite canlaw|short title =An Act to Incorporate the Institute of Accountants of Newfoundland|abbr =S.N.|year =1905|chapter =16|link=http://collections.mun.ca/PDFs/cns/ActsoftheGeneralAssemblyofNewfoundland1905.pdf}}</ref> but was pressured to revoke statutory protection of its designation the following year.<ref group="na">{{Cite canlaw|short title =An Act to Amend 5 Ed. VII., Cap. 16, entitled "An Act to Incorporate the Institute of Accountants of Newfoundland"|abbr =S.N.|year =1906|chapter =29|link=http://collections.mun.ca/PDFs/cns_tools/ActsoftheGeneralAssemblyofNewfoundland1906.pdf}}</ref> This was not reversed until Newfoundland joined Confederation in 1949.<ref group="na">{{Cite canlaw|short title =Chartered Accountants Act, 1949|abbr =S.N.|year =1949|chapter =30|link=http://collections.mun.ca/PDFs/cns_tools/StatutesofNewfoundland1949.pdf}}</ref>

====Attempt to nationalize the profession==== Tensions erupted following a disciplinary hearing in 1890 held by the Institute of Accountants of Ontario into an audit conducted with respect to [[Confederation Life]].{{sfn|Richardson|1993b|p=561}} While the action itself affirmed the importance of auditor independence, it caused a rift in the IAO membership and the resignation of several prominent members of the governing Council in 1891.{{sfn|Richardson|1993b|p=561}}
The early CA bodies, with the exception of the AAM, also started to relax their entrance requirements to allow the admission of accountants who were not in public practice.{{sfn|Richardson|1993b|p=563}} An initial effort to create a national organization in 1901 was quashed due to local opposition, but this caused a concerted effort, sponsored by the AAM, to create one that would be restricted to practicing accountants.{{sfn|Richardson|1993b|p=563}} As a result, the Dominion Association of Chartered Accountants ("DACA") was created in 1902, in an attempt to create a national status for the profession through direct entry of qualified applicants to membership.<ref group="na">{{Cite canlaw|short title =An Act to incorporate the Dominion Association of Chartered Accountants|abbr =S.C.|year =1902|chapter =58|link= https://archive.org/stream/actsofparl1902v02cana#page/67/mode/1up}}</ref>
Ontario passed an Act in 1908 granting the ICAO exclusive rights to the CA designation,<ref group="na">{{Cite canlaw|short title = An Act to revise and amend The Chartered Accountants Act|abbr = S.O.|year = 1908|chapter = 42|link = https://archive.org/stream/statutesofprovin1908onta#page/386/mode/2up}}</ref> and, on DACA's petition, the [[Governor in Council]] [[Disallowance and reservation|disallowed]] it in 1909, on grounds of [[Paramountcy (Canada)|federal paramountcy]] in having created a national body, as described in a memo by [[Minister of Justice and Attorney General of Canada]] [[Allen Bristol Aylesworth|Sir Allen Aylesworth]] recommending the measure.<ref group="na">{{cite web|title = P.C. 870: Disallowance Statute of Ontario, Cap. 42., intituled An Act to Revise and Amend the Chartered Accountants Act - Min. Just. |url = http://www.collectionscanada.gc.ca/databases/orders/001022-119.01-e.php?&sisn_id_nbr=129618&page_sequence_nbr=1&interval=20&&PHPSESSID=tdt5nh3t9kij5upqh8e00cu393|date = April 19, 1909|publisher = Privy Council Office}}, {{cite web|title = P.C. 871: Disallowance Ontario Act re. Chartered Accountants |url = http://www.collectionscanada.gc.ca/databases/orders/001022-119.01-e.php?&sisn_id_nbr=129619&page_sequence_nbr=1&interval=20&&PHPSESSID=ac6b4r8eth8q4ufb6e6cs9i487|date = April 23, 1909|publisher = Privy Council Office}}</ref> A subsequent 1910 Act<ref group="na">{{Cite canlaw|short title = An Act to revise and amend The Chartered Accountants Act|abbr = S.O.|year = 1910|chapter = 79|link = https://archive.org/stream/statutesofprovin1910onta#page/670/mode/2up}}</ref> was disallowed for similar reasons in 1911.<ref group="na">P.C. 610, P.C. 611 (March 24, 1911)</ref> With the mediation of the President of the British [[Society of Incorporated Accountants]] at a meeting in Chicago, the ICAO and DACA leaders subsequently reached an agreement in which DACA would be reorganized as a federation of the provincial Institutes effective from 1909.{{sfn|Richardson|1993a|pp=99, 220{{en dash}}221}}{{efn|A concurrent intercession by the [[Colonial Office]] ensured that British CAs would be able to gain admission to Canadian CA bodies, thus introducing recognition provisions into Canadian practice.{{sfn|Richardson|1993b|p=568}}}} The Act was subsequently passed again in 1911, with a concession granted to accountants who were members of DACA on December 16, 1909.<ref name="CA1911" group="na">{{Cite canlaw|short title = An Act respecting Chartered Accountants|abbr = S.O.|year = 1911|chapter = 48|link = https://archive.org/stream/statutesofprovin1911onta#page/410/mode/2up}}</ref>
DACA would become the [[Canadian Institute of Chartered Accountants]] in 1951.<ref group="na">{{Cite canlaw|short title =An Act respecting the Dominion Association of Chartered Accountants|abbr =S.C.|year =1951|chapter =89|link= https://archive.org/stream/actsofparl1951v02cana#page/113/mode/1up}}</ref> It would expand internationally in 1973, when the Institute of Chartered Accountants of Bermuda was incorporated and subsequently obtained affiliation with the CICA.<ref>{{cite news |last= Fox|first= David|date= July 9, 2014|title= Bermuda accountants unite under single umbrella organisation|url= http://www.royalgazette.com/article/20140709/BUSINESS03/140709721|work= [[The Royal Gazette (Bermuda)|The Royal Gazette]]|location= [[Hamilton, Bermuda]]}}</ref>
===Certified general accountants=== The creation of large business and governmental organizations increased the demand for accountants on their payrolls, which called for efforts to address their unique needs without the necessity of [[apprenticeship]]s demanded by the CA firms.{{sfn|Richardson|1996|p=89}} The Canadian Association of Accountants was formed in 1908,{{sfn|Richardson|1996|p=89}} arising from a technical self-study group of accountants working at the [[Canadian Pacific Railway]],{{sfn|Richardson|2000|p=110}} which led to the creation of the General Accountants Association in 1913.{{efn|It had to change its name because of opposition from the CA bodies, as "CAA" would have been too similar a designation to use.{{sfn|Richardson|1996|p=89}}}}<ref group="na">{{Cite canlaw|short title =An Act to incorporate the General Accountants Association|abbr =S.C.|year =1913|chapter =116|link= https://archive.org/stream/actsofparl1913v02cana#page/193/mode/1up}}</ref> Despite initial assurances that its members would refrain from practicing public accounting, it began advertising examinations in that field in 1917, thus triggering conflicts with the CA bodies that would last for decades.{{sfn|Richardson|1993b|p=573}}
Because of such protracted opposition, it was only in 1999 that the GAA was able to change its name to the [[Certified General Accountants Association of Canada]].<ref group="na">{{Cite canlaw|short title =An Act respecting the Certified General Accountants Association of Canada|abbr =S.C.|year =1999|chapter =38|link= https://archive.org/stream/actsofparl1999v02cana#page/n296/mode/1up}}</ref> Over the years, portions of its membership would be admitted into membership of other professional bodies, such as the admission into Quebec's Association of Accountants in 1920,<ref group="na">S.Q. 1919-20, c. 118</ref> the CGA/CA merger in Quebec in 1946,{{sfn|Richardson|1993b|p=592}} the CGA/CPA merger in 1949,{{sfn|Richardson|1993b|p=595}} and the CGA/CPA merger in Manitoba in 1950.{{sfn|Richardson|1993b|p=595}}

===Cost and management accounting: from CA possession to the creation of RIAs and CMAs=== Towards the end of the [[First World War]], several significant issues forced organizations to invest resources into the creation of [[cost accounting]] functions:{{sfn|Richardson|1993b|p=566}}
:* the [[Russian Revolution]], together with worldwide labour unrest, created pressure on business organizations to demonstrate that they were earning fair returns; :* wartime procurement by the [[Imperial Munitions Board]] and the introduction of [[income tax]]<ref group="na">{{Cite canlaw|short title = The Business Profits War Tax Act, 1916|abbr = S.C.|year = 1916|chapter = 11|link = https://archive.org/stream/actsofparl1916v01cana#page/60/mode/2up}}</ref><ref group="na">{{Cite canlaw|short title = The Income War Tax Act, 1917|abbr = S.C.|year = 1917|chapter = 28|link = https://archive.org/stream/actsofparl1917v01cana#page/170/mode/2up}}</ref> necessitated proving the actual cost of manufacturing goods; and :* the high rate of postwar bankruptcies brought about by the [[Post–World War I recession]] and the [[Depression of 1920–21]] created the need to demonstrate that the price of manufactured goods covered their cost.
In a move designed to prevent the newly-created General Accountants Association from moving into that field,{{sfn|Richardson|2000|p=110}} DACA created the Canadian Society of Cost Accountants ("CSCA"), with membership originally restricted to chartered accountants.<ref>{{cite journal |author=<!--Staff writer(s); no by-line.--> |title= The Canadian Society of Cost Accountants|url= https://archive.org/stream/canadianchartere10canauoft#page/30/mode/2up|journal= The Canadian Chartered Accountant|location= Toronto|publisher= Dominion Association of Chartered Accountants|date= July 1920|volume = X|issue = 1|pages = 31{{en dash}}34|accessdate= June 24, 2014}}</ref>
The CSCA would initiate efforts to standardize education in cost accounting, and entered into an affiliation agreement with the US [[National Association of Cost Accountants]] in 1922.{{sfn|Richardson|1993b|p=580}} When the CSCA tried to obtain NACA's educational materials at a more reasonable cost in 1926, NACA proposed a merger of the two organizations. This was rejected, and the affiliation was subsequently dissolved.{{sfn|Richardson|1993b|pp=582-583}} The Society began to issue "Certificates of efficiency" in 1927 to its graduates.{{sfn|Allan|1982|p= 21}}{{sfn|Richardson|1996|p=90}}
In the 1930s, there would be internal tensions as to what areas of company accounting the CSCA should focus on, and, in 1939, members wishing to concentrate more on [[management accounting]] left to form the Controllers' Institute of Canada (later part of the [[Financial Executives International|Financial Executives Institute]]).{{sfn|Richardson|1996|p=90}}
When provincial societies began to be formed in 1941, the "Registered Industrial and Cost Accountant" ("RIA") was created for its members.{{sfn|Richardson|2000|p=112}}<ref group="na">{{Cite canlaw|short title = The Society of Industrial and Cost Accountants of Ontario Act, 1941|abbr = S.O.|year = 1941|chapter = 77|link = https://archive.org/stream/statutesofprovin1941onta#page/316/mode/2up}}</ref> This initiative was generally accepted in most provinces, but there was resistance in British Columbia as the promoters of that effort were only CGAs and independent accountants.{{sfn|Richardson|1993b|p=591}} It would pass only when the enabling Act specified that the RIA designation was available only to those members who were also CAs.{{sfn|Richardson|1993b|p=591}}
The designation was simplified as "Registered Industrial Accountant" in some, but not all, provinces around 1967.<ref group="na">{{Cite canlaw|short title = The Society of Industrial Accountants of Ontario Act, 1967|abbr = S.O.|year = 1967|chapter = 129|link = https://archive.org/stream/statutesofprovin1967onta#page/548/mode/2up}}</ref> It would be replaced by the [[Certified Management Accountants of Canada|Certified Management Accountant]] ("CMA") designation beginning in 1976,{{sfn|Richardson|1993b|p=611}} but the province-by-province implementation would be completed only in 1985.

===Certified public accountants: the first CPAs=== The first Canadian CPA designation arose from several parallel moves:
:* In Quebec, the Licentiate in Accountancy was first granted by [[McGill University]] in 1918,<ref>{{cite web |url= https://www.mcgill.ca/desautels/about/history|title= Desautels: History|author=<!--Not stated--> |website= mcgill.ca|publisher= [[Desautels Faculty of Management]], [[McGill University]]|access-date= September 14, 2017}}</ref> which was granted statutory recognition as a professional designation in 1920.<ref group="na">{{Cite canlaw|short title =Loi constituant en corporation l'Association des comptables|abbr =S.Q.|year =1919-20|chapter =118|link= https://www.bibliotheque.assnat.qc.ca/DepotNumerique_v2/AffichageFichier.aspx?idf=126287}}{{fr-icon}}</ref> It was subsequently replaced by "Certified Public Accountant" in 1927.<ref group="na">{{Cite canlaw|short title =Loi modifiant la Loi des comptables|abbr =S.Q.|year =1927|chapter =61|link= https://www.bibliotheque.assnat.qc.ca/DepotNumerique_v2/AffichageFichier.aspx?idf=123700}}{{fr-icon}}</ref> :* In English Canada, the Society of Incorporated Accountants and Auditors was formed in 1918 and incorporated in 1919 by members of the GAA.<ref group="na">{{cite journal |author=<!--Staff writer(s); no by-line.--> |date= December 13, 1919|title= The Society of Incorporated Accountants and Auditors|url= http://www.collectionscanada.gc.ca/databases/canada-gazette/093/001060-119.01-e.php?document_id_nbr=14647&f=p|journal= [[Canada Gazette]]|volume= 53|issue= 24|page= 1783}}</ref> It would become the United Accountants and Auditors of Canada in 1920,<ref group="na">{{cite journal |author=<!--Staff writer(s); no by-line.--> |date= May 29, 1920|title= Society of Incorporated Accountants and Auditors|url= http://www.collectionscanada.gc.ca/databases/canada-gazette/093/001060-119.01-e.php?document_id_nbr=6680&f=p|journal= [[Canada Gazette]]|volume= 53|issue= 48|page= 4140}}</ref> conferring the "United Accountant" ("UA") designation.{{sfn|Richardson|1993a|pp=221-222}}{{efn|The UA designation was held not to infringe the protected designation of CA.<ref group="nb">{{cite CanLII|litigants=Institute of Chartered Accountants of Manitoba v Bellamy|year=1926|court=MBQB|num=242|format=canlii|parallelcite=[1926] 4 DLR 230|date=1926-07-07|courtname=auto}}</ref>}} It would later engage in a failed attempt to take over the GAA.{{sfn|Richardson|1993b|p=576}} :* In Ontario, the UAs (formed mainly from accountants and auditors working in government tax offices){{sfn|Richardson|Kilfoyle|2012|p=10}} were successful in obtaining statutory recognition as the Association of Accountants and Auditors. The designation originated as LA (Licentiate in Accountancy) during 1926{{en dash}}1931,<ref group="na">{{Cite canlaw|short title =The Association of Accountants and Auditors Act, 1926|abbr =S.O.|year =1926|chapter =124|link = https://archive.org/stream/statutesofprovin1926onta#page/682/mode/2up}}</ref> changing to IPA (Incorporated Public Accountant) during 1931{{en dash}}1936,<ref group="na">{{Cite canlaw|short title =The Association of Accountants and Auditors Act, 1931|abbr =S.O.|year =1931|chapter =143|link = https://archive.org/stream/statutesofprovin1931onta#page/504/mode/2up}}</ref> before becoming CPA.<ref group="na">{{Cite canlaw|short title =The Certified Public Accountants Act, 1936|abbr =S.O.|year =1936|chapter =68|link = https://archive.org/stream/statutesofprovin1936onta#page/290/mode/2up}}</ref>
The CPAs subsequently gained statutory recognition in most, but not all, provinces. Because of CA opposition in Nova Scotia, it was only able to use the designation of "Registered Public Accountant".{{sfn|Richardson|1993b|p=598}}
The Quebec CPAs were forced to merge with the ICAPQ in 1946 upon the reorganization of the Quebec profession.<ref group="na">S.Q. 1946, c. 47, s. 14</ref> In 1962, the CAs and CPAs agreed to merge nationally, and the remaining provincial CPA bodies either dissolved or became dormant.{{sfn|Richardson|1993b|p=603}}

===Accredited public accountants=== The "International Society of Commerce" ("ISC") was first noted in an advertisement in [[Hamilton, Ontario]], as early as 1921,{{sfn|Richardson|1993b|p=578}} and its members were conferred with the designation of "Accredited Public Accountant" ("APA"). The ISC, located in [[Winnipeg]], formed the "Institute of Accredited Public Accountants" in 1938,{{sfn|Richardson|1993b|p=587}} which was federally incorporated in 1946.{{sfn|Richardson|1993b|p=592}}<ref name="CIAPA"/> It initially attempted to organize a provincial institute in British Columbia in 1937, but failed to receive legislative approval.{{sfn|Richardson|1993b|p=587}}
When Quebec consolidated the auditing profession in 1946, APAs in the province who had practiced accounting continuously from 1942 received statutory recognition in Quebec.<ref>S.Q. 1946, c. 47,s. 28</ref> The APA designation later received statutory protection in New Brunswick, Manitoba and Saskatchewan.
An attempt was made to form a body in Ontario by way of [[private bill]] in 1949,<ref group="nc">[https://archive.org/stream/v1ontariobills1949ontauoft#page/65/mode/1up Bill 5, 1st Session, 23rd Legislature] (Ontario, 1949)</ref> but it was withdrawn at second reading on grounds advanced by the CA and CPA bodies that a [[public bill]] would be a more appropriate choice for action.<ref name="HansardON1949" group="nc">{{cite hansard |jurisdiction= Ontario|title= Institute of Accredited Public Accountants of Ontario|url= https://archive.org/stream/v2hansard1949ontauoft#page/1223/mode/1up|house= [[Legislative Assembly of Ontario]]|date= March 24, 1949|page_start= 1223|page_end= 1226}}</ref> That option was never subsequently pursued. Similar efforts to secure recognition in British Columbia and Alberta were also pursued at the time,<ref name="HansardON1949" group="nc"/> but they failed as well. Provincial societies were later organized in British Columbia and Ontario in 1957.{{sfn|Richardson|1993b|pp=597, 599}}
The APAs would later consolidate with other accounting organizations. They merged with the CPAs in New Brunswick in 1952, but other APAs revived the organization in 1961.{{efn|reactivated upon [[writ of mandamus]] issued by the [[New Brunswick Court of Appeal]]<ref group="nb">{{cite CanLII|litigants=Ex Parte Goodwin et al|link=|year=1961|court=nbca|num=421|format=canlii|parallelcite=27 DLR (2d) 667|date=1961-03-24|courtname=auto}}</ref>}} Later efforts by other provincial bodies to merge with the CGAs proved to be more conclusive. The Ontario society, however, decided in 1963 to restrict its membership to those members who held public accounting licenses. As no future licenses would be conferred on APAs after 1962 as a result of that year's reorganization of the Public Accountants Council, it would gradually cease to exist over time.{{sfn|Richardson|1993b|p=603}}
While the APA designation is not now recognized by any Canadian jurisdiction as a professional designation in active usage, the Canadian Institute of Accredited Public Accountants continues to exist,<ref name="CIAPA">{{cite web |url= https://www.ic.gc.ca/app/scr/cc/CorporationsCanada/fdrlCrpDtls.html?corpId=462195|title= Federal Corporation Information - 046219-5|author=<!--Not stated--> |website=ic.gc.ca|access-date= April 11, 2018}}</ref> in alliance with the Society of Professional Accountants of Canada.{{sfn|Richardson|Kilfoyle|2012|p=13}}<ref>{{cite web |url= https://www.ic.gc.ca/app/scr/cc/CorporationsCanada/fdrlCrpDtls.html?corpId=2744503|title= Federal Corporation Information - 274450-3|author=<!--Not stated--> |website=ic.gc.ca|access-date= April 11, 2018}}</ref> The SPAC confers the APA designation as an [[title of honor|honorary title]] to [[registered professional accountant|Registered Professional Accountant]]s of distinction.<ref>{{cite web |url= http://professionalaccountant.org/about-spac/designations/|title= Designations|author=<!--Not stated--> |website= professionalaccountant.org|publisher= Society of Professional Accountants of Canada|access-date= April 11, 2018}}</ref>

==Creation of uniform accounting standards== From 1946, the chartered accountants took the initiative to codify [[generally accepted accounting principles]] and [[generally accepted auditing standards]] in Canada:<ref>{{cite web |url= http://accountinghistory.blogspot.ca/2011/11/brief-history-of-evolution-of.html|title= A Brief History of Accounting and Auditing Standards in Canada|last= Roy|first= Paul-Émile|date= November 16, 2011|website= accountinghistory.blogspot.ca|publisher= Digital Archives for Chartered Accountants}}</ref>
:* DACA's Accounting and Auditing Research Committee began to issuing bulletins in 1946, setting out recommended standards of practice on accounting and auditing. :* The CICA started the production of research studies in 1963 on topics of current interest to the profession. :* The ''CICA Handbook'' was created in 1968 to consolidate the CICA's pronouncements. Its requirements would attain mandatory in 1975, through regulations issued under the ''[[Canada Business Corporations Act]]''.<ref group="na">currently the {{Cite canlaw|link= http://laws-lois.justice.gc.ca/eng/regulations/SOR-2001-512/section-70.html|type= reg|regtitle= Canada Business Corporations Regulations, 2001|regnumber= SOR/2001-512}}</ref> :* The [[International Financial Reporting Standards]] and [[International Auditing Standards]] would be incorporated by reference in the ''Handbook'', effective in 2011. :* It would be renamed in 2014 as the ''CPA Canada Handbook''.<ref>{{cite web |url= https://www.cpacanada.ca/en/business-and-accounting-resources/cpa-canada-handbook-the-standards-and-guidance-collection|title= CPA Canada Handbook: The standards and guidance collection|author=<!--Not stated--> |publisher= [[CPA Canada]] |access-date= April 12, 2018}}</ref>
==Licensing of public accounting== In addition to conferring exclusive rights to use specified designations on the members of the various professional bodies, most provinces have also required those who pursued [[public accounting]] to obtain a separate permit. The permit is issued by:
#a specified professional body, either with or without the supervision of a provincial agency; #a provincial agency (which could be effectively dominated by a professional body), either generally or where a qualified accountant does not belong to a specified body (as in BC from 1973).<ref group="na">''Companies Act'', S.B.C. 1973, c. 18, s. 203; currently {{Cite canlaw|short title =Business Corporations Act|abbr =S.B.C.|year =2002|chapter =57|part =7|division =4|link=http://www.bclaws.ca/civix/document/id/complete/statreg/02057_08}}</ref>{{sfn|Richardson|1993b|p=609}}

==Consolidation: Rise of the Chartered Professional Accountants (2012-)== ===Implementation by jurisdiction=== The various provincial bodies were federated nationally in the following bodies:
:* [[Canadian Institute of Chartered Accountants]] :* [[Certified General Accountants Association of Canada]] :* [[Society of Management Accountants of Canada]]
After a failed merger attempt in 2004, the CAs and CMAs began new discussions in 2011, and invited the CGAs to participate.<ref>{{cite news |last= Buckstein|first= Jeff|date= July 2011|title= Two out of three in on merger talks|url= http://www.thebottomlinenews.ca/index.php?section=article&articleid=519|dead-url= yes|work= The Bottom Line|archive-url= https://web.archive.org/web/20120426010539/http://www.thebottomlinenews.ca/index.php?section=article&articleid=519|archive-date= April 26, 2012}}</ref> While the three national bodies supported merger discussions, there was significant tension among their memberships, notably within the CAs,<ref>{{cite news |last= Buckstein|first= Jeff|date= March 2012|title= Case for unity to be laid out|url= http://www.thebottomlinenews.ca:80/index.php?section=article&articleid=564|dead-url= yes|work= The Bottom Line|archive-url= https://web.archive.org/web/20120221165608/http://www.thebottomlinenews.ca:80/index.php?section=article&articleid=564|archive-date= February 21, 2012}}</ref> and at one point the CGAs and CMAs in Ontario withdrew from talks because of concerns over the potential loss of their identity.<ref>{{cite news |last= Buckstein|first= Jeff|date= August 2012|title= Uneasy calm after bruising merger battles|url= http://www.thebottomlinenews.ca:80/index.php?section=article&articleid=587|dead-url= yes|work= The Bottom Line|archive-url= https://web.archive.org/web/20120811034246/http://www.thebottomlinenews.ca:80/index.php?section=article&articleid=587|archive-date= August 11, 2012}}</ref> Proponents of the proposal argued that it would strengthen the influence, relevance and contribution of the Canadian accounting profession with domestic and international stakeholders and serve the public interest through common codes of conduct, disciplinary systems and licensing regimes.<ref>{{Cite news|last1= Kirby|first1= Michael|author-link1= Michael J. L. Kirby|url=http://business.financialpost.com/fp-comment/let-ca-cma-and-cga-give-way-to-cpa|title=Let CA, CMA and CGA give way to CPA|work=Financial Post|date=June 25, 2012}}</ref>
Quebec would be the first province to consolidate the profession in 2012.<ref group="na">{{Cite canlaw|short title = Chartered Professional Accountants Act|abbr = S.Q.|year = 2012|chapter = 11|link = http://www2.publicationsduquebec.gouv.qc.ca/dynamicSearch/telecharge.php?type=5&file=2012C11A.PDF}}</ref> This triggered a succession of similar moves in other jurisdictions, which became functionally complete in 2014 with [[CPA Canada]] as the umbrella organization,<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.theglobeandmail.com/report-on-business/canadian-accountants-merge-under-cpa-designation/article19299464/|title=Canadian accountants merge under CPA designation|last=McFarland|first=Janet|date=2014-06-23|access-date=2017-06-04|language=en-ca}}</ref> but would be formally completed only in 2018:

===Impact on the Canadian landscape=== During the years running up to the 2012-2018 consolidation, as well as thereafter, there has been debate as to the practical impact of the merger.
The 2010-2011 CA/CMA position paper on the proposed merger gave five reasons why it should be pursued:{{sfn|Richardson|Kilfoyle|2012|pp=19-22}}
#The existing regulatory framework was complex and costly. #The differences in the functions pursued by the various designation holders were disappearing. #A strong Canadian voice was needed on the world stage. #It was necessary to compete with other accounting designations that were going global, such as the [[Chartered Global Management Accountant]] (promoted by the [[American Institute of Certified Public Accountants]] and the [[Chartered Institute of Management Accountants]]) and [[CPA Australia]]. #It was desirable to act proactively, instead of waiting for reforms imposed by various governments.
There was significant resistance by the CA membership at the time, who were concerned that their collective image would be diminished as a result.<ref>{{cite journal |last1= Richardson|first1= Alan J.|last2= Jones|first2= D.G. Brian|year= 2007|title= Professional "brand", personal identity and resistance to change in the Canadian accounting profession: a comparative history of two accounting association merger negotiations|url= http://journals.sagepub.com/doi/10.1177/1032373207076035|journal= Accounting History|publisher= |volume= 12|issue= 2|pages= 135{{en dash}}164|doi= 10.1177/1032373207076035|issn=1032-3732|accessdate=May 16, 2014}} {{closed access}}</ref>
Following the consolidation, the following observations have been made:
#Based on a [[social network theory]] analysis, it appears that those associated with the former chartered accountant bodies have generally had a disproportionate impact in the attainment of [[political power]] within the new CPA bodies, extending even to ousting the [[knowledge base]] that had been accumulated within the other legacy bodies.<ref>{{cite journal |last1= Richardson|first1= Alan J.|date= 2017|title= Merging the Profession: A Social Network Analysis of the Consolidation of the Accounting Profession in Canada|url= |journal= Accounting Perspectives|volume= 16|issue= 2|pages= 83–104|doi= 10.1111/1911-3838.12139}} {{closed access}}</ref> #The new CPA bodies have adopted a more passive approach in recruiting new members, in contrast to the activity undertaken by the previous legacy bodies.<ref>{{cite journal |last1= Brouard|first1= François|last2= Bujaki|first2= Merridee|last3= Durocher|first3= Sylvain|date=2017 |title= Attracting Prospective Professional Accountants Before and After the CPA Merger in Canada|url= |journal= Accounting Perspectives|volume= 16|issue= 2|pages= 105–127|doi= 10.1111/1911-3838.12138}} {{closed access}}</ref>

{{Multiple issues| {{Notability|bio|date=October 2015}} {{Orphan|date=October 2015}} {{Tone|date=October 2015}} {{Prose|date=November 2015}} {{BLP sources|date=November 2015}}{{external links|date=May 2018}} }} Dr. '''Daniella Abreu''', is a Brazilian civil engineer and entrepreneur. She was sustainability manager for international infrastructure and building projects in Europe, USA and Latin America at the Swedish multinational construction and development company [[Skanska]]. In 2013 she founded Sustainpolis.
==Education== Daniella Abreu graduated from two Brazilian universities with one degree in civil engineering from [[Federal University of Santa Catarina]] (UFSC) and a post grad course in political science from [[Universidade do Estado de Santa Catarina]] (UDESC). During her studies, she became the first female president of the company EPEC (Escritório Piloto de Engenharia Civil), worked as mathematics assistant lecturer for Curso e Colegio Energia, worked for the companies Prosul and RCD.
Daniella Abreu continued her studies at [[The University of Birmingham]] and finished her PhD in civil engineering ''Sustainable Assessment for Geotechnical Projects''. During her studies, she volunteered for [[Engineers Without Borders]], volunteered for the [[Institute of Civil Engineers]], and started to work as senior environmental and sustainability advisor for the Civil Engineering operating unit of [[Skanska]] in the UK regarding tenders for roads, tunnels and energy facilities.
==Career== After having completed her PhD, she was promoted as sustainability manager of the building operating unit of Skanska UK: tenders and construction of educational, health care and commercial buildings.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.constructionnews.co.uk/events/cn-specialists-awards/construction-news-specialists-awards-2014-judges-profiles-contractors/8653329.article|title=Construction News Specialists Awards 2014 judges' profiles: contractors|work=Construction News|access-date=2018-12-03|language=en}}</ref>
She moved in 2011 to Skanska ID, the international infrastructure development operating unit of Skanska: sustainability strategy, corporate responsibility and sustainability management for infrastructure projects (up to two billion dollars) in Europe, USA and Latin America.<ref>{{cite web|author= |url=https://www.forumforthefuture.org/greenfutures/articles/greener-bricks-build-with |title=Greener bricks to build with |publisher=Forum for the Future |date=2011-11-09 |accessdate=2015-11-15}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=KY0Cutba5ks |title=Our Journey to Deep Green |publisher=YouTube |date=2012-10-12 |accessdate=2015-11-15}}</ref>
In 2013, she left Skanska and founded Sustainpolis,<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.engineeringbecause.com/news/civil-structural-engineering/219/engineering-doctor-injects-knowledge-into-hot-young-engineers |title=Civil Engineering Doctor Plans To Inject Knowledge Into Hot Young Engineers' Minds |publisher=EngineeringBecause |date= |accessdate=2015-11-15}}</ref> a Belgium-based company specialized in promoting partnerships for international sustainable projects.
==Additional activities==
She was guest lecturer at: [[The University of Birmingham]], [[City University of London]], [[King's College London]].
She volunteered to support projects at: The Westminster Sustainability Business Forum, [[Large Cities Climate Leadership Group|C40]], [[Cambridge Institute for Sustainability Leadership]] Programme.
She was a member of the low carbon editorial board for [[Construction News]].
She was a judge for the Construction News Specialist Awards in 2013 and 2014.<ref>{{cite web|last=Barker |first=Katie |url=http://www.cnplus.co.uk/home/awards/cn-specialists-awards/construction-news-specialists-awards-2014-judges-profiles-contractors/8653329.article#.VhucLbSqqkp |title=Construction News Specialists Awards 2014 judges' profiles: contractors | Extra Online | Construction News |publisher=Cnplus.co.uk |date=2013-09-20 |accessdate=2015-11-15}}</ref>
She is an advisor for the Livable Cities Project.
She is an advisory board member for World Cities Network.
She is a member of [[Chatham House]].
She is listed on the ‘Top 500 Influences and Players Active on Twitter in the Built Environment’.
==Publications== * ''Sustainable Assessment for Geotechnical Projects'': [http://www.etheses.bham.ac.uk/3034/1/Holt11PhD.pdf 1] * ''Embedding sustainability into geotechnics''. Part A: methodology: [http://www.icevirtuallibrary.com/content/issue/ensu/163/3%20www.icevirtuallibrary.com/content/issue/ensu/163/3 2] * ''Why is sustainability important in Geotechnical Engineering?'': [http://www.ascelibrary.org/doi/abs/10.1061/40971(310)102 3] * ''Sustainable Geotechnical Design'': [http://www.ascelibrary.org/doi/abs/10.1061/41095(365)298%20http://www.ascelibrary.org/doi/abs/10.1061/41095(365)298 4]

{{Use dmy dates|date=September 2017}} {{Use British English|date=September 2017}} {{Infobox person | name = Donald Brydon | image = | alt = | caption = | birth_name = | birth_date = 1945 | birth_place = | death_date = <!-- {{Death date and age|df=yes|YYYY|MM|DD|YYYY|MM|DD}} (death date then birth date) --> | death_place = | nationality = British | other_names = | occupation = Businessman | years_active = | known_for = | notable_works = }}
'''Donald Hood Brydon''' {{post-nominals|country=GBR|CBE}} (born 1945) is a British businessman who is [[Chairman]] of the [[London Stock Exchange Group]] and the [[Sage Group]].<ref>{{cite web|title=Donald Brydon CBE|url=http://www.royalmailgroup.com/donald-brydon-remuneration-committee|publisher=Royal Mail Group|accessdate=15 May 2014}}</ref>
He was previously Chairman of [[Royal Mail]], [[Smiths Group]], the [[London Metal Exchange]], [[Amersham plc]], [[Taylor Nelson Sofres]], [[ifs School of Finance]], the [[Medical Research Council (United Kingdom)|Medical Research Council]] and [[EveryChild]] and a Director of [[Allied Domecq]] and [[Scottish Power]].
== Biography == Brydon went to [[George Watson's College]], before studying at the [[University of Edinburgh]] and graduating in Mathematical Science in 1967. During this time he was chairman of the University's Conservative Association alongside his fellow [[George Watson's College|Watsonian]] [[Malcolm Rifkind]], who was secretary. He was also elected President of [[Edinburgh University Students' Association|Edinburgh University Union]]. Brydon remained in Edinburgh to teach at the University for several years after graduation.<ref>{{Cite news|url = https://www.telegraph.co.uk/finance/newsbysector/mediatechnologyandtelecoms/2790143/Profile-Donald-Brydon-Chairman-Taylor-Nelson-Sofres.html|title = Profile: Donald Brydon, Chairman, Taylor Nelson Sofres|last = |first = |date = 18 May 2008|work = The Telegraph|accessdate = 16 May 2014}}</ref>
In 1977 Brydon began a 20-year career working at [[Barclays Center|Barclays]], during which time he became Chairman and Chief Executive of the company's investment arm, [[Barclays#1980 to_2000|BZW Investment Management]]. From 1997 to 2002 Brydon was Chief Executive Officer at [[AXA|AXA Investment Managers SA]]. In 2004 Brydon was awarded a [[Order of the British Empire|CBE]] for services to the financial industry.<ref>{{cite web|title=Donald H. Brydon CBE,BSc|url=http://investing.businessweek.com/research/stocks/private/person.asp?personId=226284|publisher=Bloomberg Businessweek|accessdate=15 May 2014}}</ref>
As Chairman of the Royal Mail, Brydon was paid an annual salary £200,000, working two days a week. Whilst in office for a period of six years Brydon oversaw the [[Royal Mail#Privatisation|controversial privatisation]] of the 499-year-old institution.<ref>{{cite news|title=Royal Mail chairman Donald Brydon re-appointed|url=https://www.independent.co.uk/news/business/news/royal-mail-chairman-donald-brydon-reappointed-7583156.html|accessdate=15 May 2014|newspaper=The Independent|date=23 March 2012}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|title=Chair Royal Mail Group|url=https://www.whatdotheyknow.com/request/chair_royal_mail_group|publisher=whatdotheyknow.com|accessdate=15 May 2014}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|title=Royal Mail to cut 1,600 jobs following privatisation to 'reduce costs'|url=https://www.independent.co.uk/news/business/news/royal-mail-to-cut-1600-jobs-following-privatisation-to-reduce-costs-9213817.html|accessdate=15 May 2014|newspaper=The Independent|date=25 March 2014}}</ref>
He resigned from the Royal Mail Group in 2015 to become Chairman of the London Stock Exchange Group.<ref> {{cite web|url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/finance/markets/11686303/Royal-Mail-chair-Donald-Brydon-to-join-the-London-Stock-Exchange-board.html|title=Royal Mail chair Donald Brydon to join the London Stock Exchange board|publisher= The Telegraph|accessdate= 17 July 2018}} </ref>

{{morerefs|date=August 2018}} '''Donald E. Bently''' (October 18, 1924 - October 1, 2012{{cite web|title=Donald E. Bently, Engineer, Industry Pioneer, Philanthropist, and Businessman Dies at 87|url=http://www.businesswire.com/news/home/20121002007039/en/Donald-E.-Bently-Engineer-Industry-Pioneer-Philanthropist#.VF0GRTTF-So|publisher=[[Business Wire]]|accessdate=7 November 2014|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20150924114834/http://www.businesswire.com/news/home/20121002007039/en/Donald-E.-Bently-Engineer-Industry-Pioneer-Philanthropist#.VF0GRTTF-So|archive-date=2015-09-24|dead-url=no|df=}}) was a globally recognized authority on rotor dynamics and vibration monitoring and diagnostics, and an American entrepreneur and engineer. He was best known as the founder and former owner of [[Bently Nevada|Bently Nevada Corporation]] where he performed pioneering work in the field of instrumentation for measuring the mechanical condition of rotating machinery. He founded Bently Nevada in October, 1961, and served as its CEO until February, 2002. He sold the company to [[GE Energy]] in February, 2002, and in 2017 GE merged it into [[Baker Hughes]]. It continues to design, manufacture, and market these products and services under the Baker Hughes, a GE company, LLC brand. {{Infobox person | image = Donald_E._Bently.jpg | imagesize = 200px | alt = Donald E. Bently, an older business man in a suit, smiling | caption = Donald Emory Bently | pseudonym = | birth_name = Donald Emory Bently{{cite web |title=Donald Emory Bently Online Obituary, October 18, 1924 - October 1, 2012 |url=http://www.wittichfuneralhome.com/obituary/95327/Donald-Bently/ |website=Muscatine Funeral Home - Ralph J. Wittich-Riley-Freers Funeral Home and Cremation Services |accessdate=24 August 2018 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20180825004407/http://www.wittichfuneralhome.com/obituary/95327/Donald-Bently/ |archive-date=2018-08-25 |dead-url=no |df= }} | birth_date = {{Birth date|mf=yes|1924|10|18}} | birth_place = [[Muscatine, Iowa|Muscatine]], [[Iowa]] | death_date = {{Death date and age|mf=yes|2012|10|01|1924|10|18}} | death_place = [[Carson Valley]], [[Nevada]] | resting_place = Greenwod Cemetery, Muscatine, Iowa{{findagrave|98333233}} | known_for = Inventor of eddy current proximity transducer
Founder of [[Bently Nevada]] | occupation = Engineer, inventor, businessman, philanthropist | spouse = | children = Christopher }} Following the sale of the company, Bently subsequently remained active in his other family-owned businesses representing a diverse range of interests including [[rotordynamics]], [[agriculture]], [[biofuels]], [[real estate]], [[fluid bearing|externally pressurized fluid bearings]], and machinery diagnostics. ==Education and military service== Born in Muscatine, Iowa, Bently served in the U.S. Navy during [[World War II]]{{cite web|url=http://www.iowalum.com/daa/Bently.html |title=Donald E. Bently |accessdate=2013-04-03 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130531050735/http://www.iowalum.com/daa/Bently.html |archivedate=2013-05-31 |df= }} as a [[Seabee]]. He attended the [[University of Iowa]], receiving a Bachelor of Science degree in Electrical Engineering in 1949, followed by a master's degree in Electrical Engineering in 1950.{{cite web|url=http://www.engineering.uiowa.edu/alumni-friends/honor-wall/distinguished-engineering-alumni-academy-members/donald-e-bently|title=Donald Bently - College of Engineering - The University of Iowa|website=www.engineering.uiowa.edu|access-date=2013-04-03|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20130531234603/http://www.engineering.uiowa.edu/alumni-friends/honor-wall/distinguished-engineering-alumni-academy-members/donald-e-bently|archive-date=2013-05-31|dead-url=no|df=}} Bently worked as the lead azide and mercury fulminate assembly line engineer at the [[Iowa Army Ammunition Plant|Iowa Ordnance Plant]] in [[Burlington, Iowa]]. He then worked for [[North American Aviation]] and [[Rocketdyne]] in California. He later completed graduate-level coursework at [[UC Berkeley]]{{cite web|url=http://www.bpb-co.com/corporate/founder.php|title=Externally Pressurized Porous Gas Bearings – Bently Bearings|website=Bently Bearings|access-date=2013-04-03|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120125075624/http://bpb-co.com/corporate/founder.php|archive-date=2012-01-25|dead-url=no|df=}} while working for an aerospace company. He experimented the [[eddy-current]] sensing technology that was later the foundation of Bently Nevada Corporation. ==Bently Nevada history== {{main|Bently Nevada}} During Bently's brief employment in the aerospace industry in the mid-1950s, he assisted with research into the use of electronic sensing technologies for aircraft control systems. At the time, his employer concluded that there was limited use for the eddy-current technology in aircraft controls. Bently, however, felt the technology showed commercial promise elsewhere and received permission to use it in his own endeavors. In 1956, he left to form Bently Scientific Company, manufacturing and selling eddy-current products via mail order from his garage in Berkeley, California.{{cite web |title=Donald Bently Obituary |url=http://funeralinnovations.com/obituary/95327/Donald-Bently |website=funeralinnovations.com |accessdate=22 August 2018 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20180823105708/http://funeralinnovations.com/obituary/95327/Donald-Bently |archive-date=2018-08-23 |dead-url=no |df= }} In 1961, Bently relocated the company to Minden, Nevada, and incorporated it there as Bently Nevada Corporation with three people.{{cite journal | url=https://www.gemeasurement.com/sites/gemc.dev/files/orbit_v33n1_2013_q1.pdf |title=In-Memoriam – The Life of a Great Man |journal=Orbit|page=4|volume=33 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20180827171915/https://www.gemeasurement.com/sites/gemc.dev/files/orbit_v33n1_2013_q1.pdf |archivedate=August 27, 2018| number=1 | date=January 2013 |publisher= GE Oil & Gas}} Bently's primary application of eddy-current technology was for non-contacting displacement sensors. Often thought of as a type of electronic [[dial indicator]], such sensors are typically used to measure very small distances between the tip of the sensor and a conductive surface, such as rotating shaft. The displacements measured are extremely small, typically on the order of several thousandths of an inch. Initially, Bently's sensors were sold mainly for laboratory rather than industrial measurements. However, beginning in the early 1960s, users began to experiment with eddy-current sensors for measuring vibration on turbines, compressors, pumps, electric motors, and other [[turbomachinery]]. This application proved to be extremely successful, allowing machinery operators a practical method of observing actual shaft vibratory motion for the first time. Soon thereafter, Bently augmented his sensors with monitoring instrumentation that accepted his sensors as inputs and provided simple visual indication of the amount of vibration. Users could set alarm levels for annunication and machine shutdown purposes when vibration levels became excessive. From that time forward, Bently began to focus his company's efforts almost exclusively on instrumentation for rotating machinery condition measurements. In 2001, Bently Nevada built a new $30 million, 283,000-square-foot hadquarters outside Minden at Orchard and Buckeye, previously known as Ferris Heights.{{cite web |last1=Munson |first1=Jeff |title=GE’s purchase of Bently complete |url=https://www.tahoedailytribune.com/news/ges-purchase-of-bently-complete/ |website=Tahoe Daily Tribune |publisher=Tribune News Service |accessdate=22 August 2018 |language=en |date=January 28, 2002 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20180822213921/https://www.tahoedailytribune.com/news/ges-purchase-of-bently-complete/ |archive-date=2018-08-22 |dead-url=no |df= }} The new location consolidated operations previously located at eight different locations around Carson Valley.{{cite web |last1=Carter |first1=Sharon |title=Bently breaks ground for new facility at Science Park |url=https://www.recordcourier.com/news/local/bently-breaks-ground-for-new-facility-at-science-park/ |accessdate=22 August 2018 |language=en |date=December 19, 2001 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20180822213915/https://www.recordcourier.com/news/local/bently-breaks-ground-for-new-facility-at-science-park/ |archive-date=2018-08-22 |dead-url=no |df= }} Bently acquired the Buckeye Ranch in 1978, the former location of the Dangberg sheep operation. Bently renamed the location Bently Science Park. This specialized focus resulted in substantial growth. When Bently sold Bently Nevada to GE Energy in January 2002 for between $600 million and $900 million, the company had 1,200 people at its headquarters in Minden, Nevada and 2,100 employees worldwide, operated in more than 40 countries, and had global sales exceeding $235 million USD.{{cite web |title=GE Power Systems Completes Acquisition of Bently Nevada |url=http://www.genewsroom.com/press-releases/ge-power-systems-completes-acquisition-of-bently-nevada-270415 |website=GE Newsroom |accessdate=22 August 2018 |language=en |date=25 January 2002 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20180822214149/http://www.genewsroom.com/press-releases/ge-power-systems-completes-acquisition-of-bently-nevada-270415 |archive-date=2018-08-22 |dead-url=no |df= }} Bently said he sold Bently Nevada so he could concentrate on other interests. ==Other business interests== Bently founded other businesses, including Bently Pressurized Bearing Company, which manufactured a bearing that can hold a rotating axle in place. The technology injected [[fluid bearing|highly pressurized air]] between the bearing and the rotating machinery, preventing the axle from touching the bearing, virtually eliminating friction. === Bently Rotordynamics === In 1981, Bently established a pure research organization called Bently Rotordynamics Research Corporation (BRDRC or "Birdrock"). BRDRC's objective was to conduct rotordynamic research, furthering the knowledge of rotating machinery behavior, modeling techniques, and malfunction diagnostic methodologies. Its mission was considered complementary to Bently Nevada, with BRDRC focused on understanding how machinery behaved, and Bently Nevada focused on understanding and building instrumentation to measure machinery behavior. BRDRC made a number of important contributions to the field of rotordynamics such as a better understanding of fluid-induced instabilities, advanced models for understanding shaft crack behavior, insight into rubbing malfunctions between stationary and rotating parts, and enhancement of the rotordynamic equations via introduction of a new variable lambda (λ) which denoted the fluid circumferential average velocity ratio and more accurately modeled hydrodynamic effects. Bently was personally responsible for many of these developments, publishing his work under the auspices of BRDRC. BRDRC also introduced several new data presentation formats, such as so-called "full" spectrum plots and "acceptance region" trend plots. Its research findings were published extensively in relevant technical journals, and the research that had practical commercial applications often found its way into the Bently Nevada product line. In 2002, BRDRC was sold along with Bently Nevada to GE Energy. === Other Bently businesses === Bently founded Bently Agrowdynamics, which focused on environmentally sustainable agricultural practices and innovative uses of renewable resources. The company led reconstruction of Mud Lake Dam which had been damaged during the 1994 Double Springs Flat earthquake. They converted the 100-year-old earth filled dam to a rock filled structure, ensuring a supply of irrigation water for Bently Agrowdynamics’ South Ranch properties and improving the dam's resistance to earthquakes, protecting the surrounding community.{{cite web |title=Donald Bently {{!}} College of Engineering {{!}} The University of Iowa |url=https://www.engineering.uiowa.edu/alumni/awards/honor-wall/donald-bently |website=www.engineering.uiowa.edu |accessdate=27 August 2018 |language=en}} Other businesses included Bently Tribology Services, Bently Biofuels, Gibson Tool and Supply, and RoMaDyn, a mechanical engineering services and diagnostics company. He also held more than {{convert|38,000|acres}} of agricultural land in and around [[Douglas County, Nevada|Carson Valley, Nevada]] and numerous real estate holdings in the United States and abroad. All of Bently's businesses were privately held, allowing him to focus on a long-term strategy without the pressure of quarterly stockholder reports. This also enabled him to keep his company in the front of his field technologically. He successfully competed against subsidized Japanese companies and from U.S. government-funded entities. ===Founded ISCORMA=== A significant amount of Bently's rotordynamic research efforts were about rotor dynamic stability. In 2001, he established ISCORMA, (International Symposium on Stability Control of Rotating Machinery), a bi-annual industry event. Bently was an active organizer and participant in all ISCORMA conferences until his death. ===Work with NASA=== His expertise also led to work for NASA. He spent 2½ years studying the area where the oxygen and hydrogen fuel pumps connect to the main engines on the space shuttle following the January 1986 challenger disaster.{{cite web|last=Timko|first=Steve|title=Bently's innovations, inventions benefited many|url=http://www.rgj.com/article/20121007/LIV11/310070048/Bently-s-innovations-inventions-benefited-many?gcheck=1&nclick_check=1|work=Obituary|publisher=Reno Gazette-Journal|accessdate=10 October 2012 |deadurl=yes}} == Philanthropy and public service == Bently was a leader of and major financial supporter if [[The Institute of World Politics]].{{cite web |title=Philanthropist and entrepreneur Donald E. Bently honored at Reagan Ranch |url=https://www.iwp.edu/news_publications/detail/philanthropist-and-entrepreneur-donald-e-bently-honored-at-reagan-ranch |accessdate=24 August 2018 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20180825003700/https://www.iwp.edu/news_publications/detail/philanthropist-and-entrepreneur-donald-e-bently-honored-at-reagan-ranch |archive-date=2018-08-25 |dead-url=no |df= }} Bently purchased the Marlatt Mansion and two adjacent townhouses for the Institute. For the first 15 years, he rented the building to the Institute for $1.00 per year. He paid several million dollars to gut and completely renovate the townhouses and later donated them to the Institute. He also endowed the Donald E. Bently Chair of Political Economy.{{cite web |title=IWP mourns the passing of longtime supporter Donald E. Bently |url=https://www.iwp.edu/news_publications/detail/iwp-mourns-the-passing-of-longtime-supporter-donald-e-bently |accessdate=24 August 2018 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20180825004734/https://www.iwp.edu/news_publications/detail/iwp-mourns-the-passing-of-longtime-supporter-donald-e-bently |archive-date=2018-08-25 |dead-url=no |df= }} Bently supported local schools in Carson Valley. He donated several million dollars to [[Cal Poly State University]] in San Luis Obispo, California, and gave generously to St. Gall Catholic Church, Carson Valley United Methodist Church, and a battered women's shelter.{{cite web |last1=Gardner |first1=Sheila |title=Inventor Don Bently remembered by more than 500 at memorial |url=https://www.nevadaappeal.com/news/local/inventor-don-bently-remembered-by-more-than-500-at-memorial/ |accessdate=27 August 2018 |language=en |date=October 2012}} He helped fund the building of the new {{convert|38,338|sqft}} museum facility built in 2010 at the [[Seabee Museum and Memorial Park|U.S. Navy Seabee Museum]] at Port Hueneme, California. In 2005, he helped create a [[conservation easement]] with the [[Nature Conservancy]] that preserved the Kirman Field in northern Douglas County.{{cite web |title=Minden industrialist, philanthropist Don Bently dead at age 87 |url=https://www.recordcourier.com/news/local/minden-industrialist-philanthropist-don-bently-dead-at-age-87/ |accessdate=27 August 2018 |language=en |date=2 October 2012}} He also supported the Friends of Pine Creek Grist Mill, Muscatine Junior College and its Alumni Association, Muscatine Community College, the Lucille A. Carver Mississippi River Environmental Research Station Fund, and the University of Iowa. == Recognition == Bently was recognized with the [[American Society of Mechanical Engineers]] Frederick P. Smarro Award and R. Tom Sawyer Award, and the N. O. Mylestad Award from the Technical Committee on Vibration and Sound of the ASME Design Engineering Division. He was a Fellow and Life Member of the [[American Society of Mechanical Engineers]]. In 1992, he was made a foreign member of the St. Petersburg Academy of Engineering in Russia. The Board of Regents of the University and Community College System of Nevada recognized Bently as a 2002 Distinguished Nevadan. ==Publications== Bently co-authored the textbook ''Fundamentals of Rotating Machinery Diagnostics'' which is used at major universities.Bently has authored more than 140 papers and articles dealing [[rotordynamics]] and/or [[condition monitoring]] technologies. Many are peer-reviewed and have been published in various technical journals such as those of the [[American Society of Mechanical Engineers]] (ASME). == References == {{reflist|30em}} ==External links== * [http://bentlyenterprises.com Bently Enterprises] * [http://bentlyranch.com/ Bently Ranch] * [http://www.romadyn.com Romadyn] {{DEFAULTSORT:Bently, Donald E.}} [[Category:American businesspeople]] [[Category:2012 deaths]] [[Category:1924 births]] [[Category:People from Muscatine, Iowa]] [[Category:University of Iowa alumni]]

'''''El Economista''''' is a [[Mexico|Mexican]] business and economics newspaper. Founded in 1989, it publishes from Monday to Friday in five columns. One of its most distinctive features is the unusual tone of pink-orange paper it's printed on.
== Contents ==
Recently, ''El Economista'' has tried to renew itself. It now includes several add-ins such as monthly or weekly supplements covering important business and personal finance issues like: Mutual Funds, Real Estate, Entrepreneurship, Health, Fashion, Construction and Transport.
From Monday to Friday the newspaper prints an Editorial Column, From Europe, a digest of ''[[The New York Times]]'', ''La Plaza'' (sports, showbiz and cultural section), the usual Market Information, a Personal Finance section, Small Businesses, a Column by an academic of respected business schools ([[Instituto Tecnológico Autónomo de México|ITAM]], [[ITESM]], [[IPADE]], [[Universidad Anáhuac]], and so on) Finance, Economics, National Politics and Local Politics. Finally, the editorial page.
Some of the editorialists include Ricardo Medina, Maricarmen Cortés, Luis Mercado and Isaac Katz.
==External links== * [http://www.eleconomista.com.mx/ ''El Economista'']
