{{EngvarB|date=September 2013}} {{Use dmy dates|date=September 2013}} {{Infobox business park | name = Green Park Business Park | image = [[File:Green Park and Longwater.jpg|300px]] | caption = | location = [[Reading, Berkshire|Reading]], [[Berkshire]], UK | map_type = United Kingdom Reading | map_caption = Location within Reading | map_size = 300px | address = Green Park
Reading
RG2 6GP | coordinates = {{coord|51.424354|-0.991361}} | opening_date = | closing_date = | developer = | construction_cost = | manager = | owner = | architect = | number_of_tenants = | number_of_workers = | size = | parking = | website = {{URL|greenpark.co.uk}} | footnotes = }} '''Green Park''' is a [[business park]] near junction 11 of the [[M4 motorway]] on the outskirts of the English [[Reading, Berkshire|town of Reading]]. The park opened in 1999, and is currently owned by [[Mapletree Investments|Mapletree]]. It covers {{convert|195|acre}} and comprises 19 office buildings arranged around the ''Longwater'', a central lake and wildlife habitat. The buildings provide {{convert|1500000|sqft}} of office space, and in excess of 6,500 people work on site.{{cite news |url=http://www.getreading.co.uk/news/berkshire-history/pick-past-topping-out-ceremony-11194399 |title=Pick of the Past: Topping out ceremony for Green Park |work=getreading.co.uk |publisher=Trinity Mirror Southern |first=Hugh |last=Fort |date=15 April 2016 |accessdate=23 April 2017 |archivedate=23 April 2017 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170423151523/http://www.getreading.co.uk/news/berkshire-history/pick-past-topping-out-ceremony-11194399 |deadurl=no}}{{cite news |url=http://www.propertyweek.com/news/offices/mapletree-completes-%C2%A3560m-green-park-buy/5082071.article |title=Mapletree completes £560m Green Park buy |work=PropertyWeek.com |publisher=Property Week |date=18 May 2016 |first=Richard |last=Williams |accessdate=23 April 2017 |archivedate=23 April 2017 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170423154838/http://www.propertyweek.com/news/offices/mapletree-completes-%C2%A3560m-green-park-buy/5082071.article |deadurl=no}}{{cite web |url=https://www.landscapeinstitute.org/case-studies/greenpark/ |title=GreenPark |publisher=Landscape Institute |date=11 July 2016 |accessdate=23 April 2017}} The site is bounded by the M4 motorway to the south, the [[Madejski Stadium]] and the [[A33 road]] to the east, the site of the proposed [[Green Park Village]] to the north, and the [[Reading–Basingstoke line|Reading to Basingstoke railway line]] to the west. From a local government perspective it is largely located within the [[borough of Reading]], but partly in the [[Shinfield|civil parish of Shinfield]] within the [[borough of Wokingham]].{{cite web |url=http://www.greenpark.co.uk/about-us/park |title=About Green Park |publisher=Green Park |accessdate=25 April 2017 |archivedate=25 April 2017 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170425133222/http://www.greenpark.co.uk/about-us/park |deadurl=no}} The development has been awarded a national [[Civic Trust Awards|Civic Trust Award]] for its landscape design, architecture and community involvement.{{cite web |url=https://www.civictrustawards.org.uk/winners/green-park |title=Green Park |publisher=[[Civic Trust Awards]] |accessdate=24 April 2017 |archivedate=24 April 2017 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170424174954/https://www.civictrustawards.org.uk/winners/green-park |deadurl=no}}{{cite news |url=http://www.getreading.co.uk/news/business/green-park-wins-civic-trust-6752293 |title=Green Park wins Civic Trust award for design, architecture and community involvement |work=getreading.co.uk |publisher=Trinity Mirror Southern |first=David |last=Millward |date=27 February 2014 |accessdate=25 April 2017 |archivedate=25 April 2017 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170425095426/http://www.getreading.co.uk/news/business/green-park-wins-civic-trust-6752293 |deadurl=no}} ==History== [[File:GreenPark Lake.jpg|thumb|The central lake makes a virtue of the necessity of flood alleviation measures]] Green Park was developed by [[Prudential plc|Prudential]] and [[Prudential Property Investment Managers|PRUPIM]] on what was once an area of low lying and poor quality agricultural land. The fact that the land was prone to flooding necessitated the construction of flood alleviation features, including the central ''Longwater'' lake and the realigned [[Foudry Brook]].{{cite web |url=http://my.greenpark.co.uk/wildlife-and-environment |title=Wildlife & environment |publisher=Green Park |accessdate=24 April 2017 |archivedate=24 April 2017 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170424180501/http://my.greenpark.co.uk/wildlife-and-environment}} The park was opened in February 1999. Initially [[Cisco Systems]] committed to taking {{convert|607000|sqft}} of office space, with options on a further {{convert|617000|sqft}}. However the bursting of the [[dot-com bubble]] in 2001 led to a severe scaling back of Cisco's requirements, and resulted in five of their buildings remaining empty for many years.{{cite book |title=Planet Property |last=Bill |first=Peter |publisher=Troubador Publishing Ltd |date=1 December 2013| isbn=9781783061266 |page=31 |url=https://books.google.co.uk/books?id=Fl88AgAAQBAJ&pg=PA31&lpg=PA31&dq=green+park+reading+cisco+dotcom&source=bl&ots=Mfa0k3XFI2&sig=cNP14UrDcxtlN_S1UiCKspCCCEY&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwj5wPrCmb3TAhUjIMAKHerlAvIQ6AEIPDAE#v=onepage&q=green%20park%20reading%20cisco%20dotcom&f=false}} The park was purchased by [[Oxford Properties]] in November 2011, and in the following year they came to an agreement with Cisco whereby the latter company paid a premium in order to surrender its leases on {{convert|517000|sqft}} of space, retaining only a much smaller amount of space. In 2014, the park was awarded a [[Civic Trust Awards|Civic Trust Award]] in the public realm class for its landscape design, architecture and community involvement. Green Park was sold to [[Mapletree Investments|Mapletree]] in May 2016 for [[Pound sterling|£]]560m.{{cite news |url=http://www.propertyweek.com/news/cisco-surrenders-reading-offices-to-oxford-properties/5040208.article |title=Cisco surrenders Reading offices to Oxford Properties |work=PropertyWeek.com |publisher=Property Week |date=24 July 2012 |first=Patrick |last=Gower |accessdate=24 April 2017 |archivedate=24 April 2017 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170424140858/http://www.propertyweek.com/news/cisco-surrenders-reading-offices-to-oxford-properties/5040208.article |deadurl=no}}{{cite news |url=http://www.readingchronicle.co.uk/news/roundup/articles/2012/10/10/63373-reading-move-for-chinese-communication-giant/ |title=Reading move for Chinese communication giant |work=Readingchronicle.co.uk |publisher=Reading Chronicle |date=10 October 2012 |accessdate=12 October 2012 |archivedate=23 April 2017 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170423152021/http://www.readingchronicle.co.uk/news/13397812.Reading_move_for_Chinese_communication_giant/ |deadurl=no}} ==Transport== Green Park is accessed from two junctions off the [[A33 road]], respectively {{convert|0.7|mi}} and {{convert|0.9|mi}} north of junction 11 of the [[M4 motorway]], and {{convert|2.4|mi}} and {{convert|2.6|mi}} south of [[Reading, Berkshire|Reading]] town centre. A system of express bus routes operated by [[Reading Buses]] and branded ''greenwave'' connects Green Park to Reading town centre, [[Reading railway station]] and a [[park and ride]] site at Mereoak south of the M4. Between Reading and Green Park frequencies vary from 8 buses per hour during weekday peak periods to hourly on Sundays.{{cite web|url=http://www.reading-buses.co.uk/files/timetables/current/greenwave%20green%20park%20times.pdf |title=Greenwave Green Park times |accessdate=25 April 2017 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170425125658/http://www.reading-buses.co.uk/files/timetables/current/greenwave%20green%20park%20times.pdf |archivedate=25 April 2017}} Plans for a [[Reading Green Park railway station|Green Park station]] on the [[Reading–Basingstoke line|Reading to Basingstoke railway line]] were first mooted in the mid-2000s. Construction was approved in April 2015, with construction expected to start in October 2016, and an opening date in December 2018. However a subsequent delay to the planned electrification of the line beyond 2019 has raised fears that it may not be possible to provide a train service to the station on its opening, as the existing diesel trains lack sufficient acceleration to add an extra stop without reducing line capacity.{{cite news |url= https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-england-berkshire-32516373 |title=Green Park railway station approved for Reading |work=News |publisher=BBC |date=30 April 2015 |accessdate=25 April 2017}}{{cite web |url=http://www.getreading.co.uk/news/reading-berkshire-news/network-rail-attempt-green-park-12658687 |title=Network Rail attempt to get Green Park Station project back on track |work=getreading.co.uk |publisher=Trinity Mirror Southern |first=Nathan |last=Hyde |date=26 February 2017 |accessdate=2 May 2017 |archivedate=2 May 2017 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170502161039/http://www.getreading.co.uk/news/reading-berkshire-news/network-rail-attempt-green-park-12658687 |deadurl=no}} [[National Cycle Route 23|Route 23]] of the [[National Cycle Network]] follows a traffic-free routing through the centre of Green Park, on its way from Reading to [[Basingstoke]].{{cite web |title=Reading to Basingstoke |url=http://www.sustrans.org.uk/sites/default/files/documents/reading20basingstoke.pdf |publisher=[[Sustrans]] |accessdate=26 April 2017 | archivedate=26 April 2017 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170426155113/http://www.sustrans.org.uk/sites/default/files/documents/reading20basingstoke.pdf}} ==Green Park wind turbine== [[File:Pond & Turbine, Green Park (geograph 4689804).jpg|thumb|Green Park wind turbine viewed from Lime Square]] The most visible feature of Green Park is an [[Enercon]] E-70{{cite news |url=https://www.highbeam.com/doc/1P3-939697861.html |title=Green energy |date=1 November 2005 |accessdate=23 April 2017 |publisher=High Beam Research |first=Terry |last=Bolsher |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170423160828/https://www.highbeam.com/doc/1P3-939697861.html |archivedate=23 April 2017 |deadurl=no}} [[wind turbine]], adjacent to the M4 motorway, and billed as ''the UK's most visible turbine''. The blades are 33 m (108 ft) long, with a tower height of 85 m (279 ft). At a wind speed of 14 ms−1 (31 mph) the machine generates 2.05 MW of electricity (less for lower wind speeds), which is enough to power around 1,500 homes. It is owned and operated by [[Ecotricity]] and was completed in November 2005.{{cite web |url=https://www.ecotricity.co.uk/our-green-energy/our-green-electricity/from-the-wind/wind-parks-gallery/green-park-reading |title=Green Park, Reading - The most visible windmill in the world…? |publisher=[[Ecotricity]] |date=20 October 2012 |archivedate=20 October 2012 |archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20121020151131/http://www.ecotricity.co.uk/our-green-energy/our-green-electricity/from-the-wind/wind-parks-gallery/green-park-reading |deadurl=no}} == Facilities == Most of the facilities for Green Park are located on Lime Square, alongside the southern access road to the park and opposite the wind turbine. This offers a day nursery, ''Childbase'', for pre-school children, as well as a play area for children up to 10 years, ''The Mad House Play & Party World''. There is also a [[Nuffield Health|Nuffield Health Fitness & Wellbeing Centre]], a waterside brasserie called ''Zest at Lime Square'', an [[Asda|Asda Click & Collect]], and a [[WH Smith]] store.{{cite web |url=http://my.greenpark.co.uk/amenities |title=Amenities in Green Park |publisher=Green Park |accessdate=26 April 2017 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170426123425/http://my.greenpark.co.uk/amenities |archivedate=26 April 2017 |deadurl=no}}{{cite web |url=http://my.greenpark.co.uk/amenities/health-fitness |title=Health & Fitness |publisher=Green Park |accessdate=26 April 2017 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170426123648/http://my.greenpark.co.uk/amenities/health-fitness |archivedate=26 April 2017 |deadurl=no}}{{cite web |url=http://my.greenpark.co.uk/amenities/shopping |title=Shopping |publisher=Green Park |accessdate=26 April 2017 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170426123851/http://my.greenpark.co.uk/amenities/shopping |archivedate=26 April 2017 |deadurl=no}} At the opposite end of the park, 100 Longwater Avenue contains the ''Byte Café'' and is home to the ''Green Park Conference Centre'', which hosts meeting rooms and amenities for various sized meetings and conferences.{{cite web |url=http://www.greenpark.co.uk/conference-centre/home |title=The Green Park Conference Centre |publisher=Mapletree |accessdate=23 April 2017 |archivedate=23 April 2017 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170423171651/http://www.greenpark.co.uk/conference-centre/home}} == Sport == The business park is adjacent to the [[Madejski Stadium]], home of [[Reading F.C.|Reading Football Club]] and the [[London Irish|London Irish rugby club]]. The UK's third largest annual running event, the [[Reading Half Marathon]] starts from within the business park, which provides the space needed for pre-race marshalling of the large numbers of competitors, and finishes in the stadium.{{cite news |url=http://www.getreading.co.uk/whats-on/whats-on-news/reading-half-marathon-2015-how-8386169 |title=Reading Half Marathon 2015: How the course changeos for this year's run |first=Jennie |last=Slevin |work=getreading.co.uk |date=6 January 2015 |publisher=Trinity Mirror Southern | accessdate=14 January 2015 | archivedate=2 April 2015 | deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150402180836/http://www.getreading.co.uk/whats-on/whats-on-news/reading-half-marathon-2015-how-8386169}} The business park is also home to the annual Green Park Triathlon which encourages participants to 'Commit to get Fit' and raise money for [[Comic Relief]].{{cite web |url=http://www.greenparktriathlon.co.uk/ |title=Green Park Triathlon |publisher=Green Park Triathlon |accessdate=23 April 2017 |archivedate=23 April 2017 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170423170952/http://www.greenparktriathlon.co.uk/}} == References == {{Reflist|30em}} == External links == * {{Commons category-inline}} * [http://www.greenpark.co.uk/ Official website] {{South East powerstations|state=collapsed}} [[Category:Buildings and structures completed in 2005]] [[Category:Business parks of England]] [[Category:Economy of Reading, Berkshire]] [[Category:Economy of Berkshire]] [[Category:Recipients of Civic Trust Awards]] [[Category:Borough of Wokingham]]

{{Use dmy dates|date=February 2013}} {{Infobox scientist | name = Sir Hilary Beckles | birth_date = {{Birth date and age|df=yes|1955|08|11}} | birth_place = [[Barbados]] | residence = | citizenship = | nationality = [[Barbadian people|Barbadian]] | fields = [[Afro-Caribbean history]], [[History of Barbados|Barbadian history]] | workplaces = [[University of the West Indies]] (1980–) | alma_mater = [[University of Hull]]
([[Bachelor of Arts|B.A.]] 1976, [[Doctor of Philosophy|Ph.D.]] 1980) | awards = [[Knight or Dame of St. Andrew (Barbados)|Knight of St. Andrew]] (2007)
[[Doctor of Letters|Honorary degree]]s from the [[University of Hull]] (2004), [[Kwame Nkrumah University of Science and Technology|KNUST]] (2009), and the [[University of Glasgow]] (2011) }} '''Sir Hilary McDonald Beckles''' [[Knight or Dame of St. Andrew (Barbados)|KA]] (born 11 August 1955) is a [[Barbados|Barbadian]] historian, he is the current [[vice-chancellor]] of the [[University of the West Indies]] (UWI) and chairman of the [[CARICOM Reparations Committee]]. Educated at the [[University of Hull]] in England, Beckles began his academic career at UWI, and was granted a personal professorship at the age of 37, becoming the youngest in the university's history. He was named pro-vice-chancellor and chairman of UWI's Board for Undergraduate Studies in 1998, and in 2002 was named [[Principal (academia)|principal]] of the university's [[Cave Hill, Saint Michael, Barbados|Cave Hill]] campus. Although his focus has mainly been on [[Afro-Caribbean history]], especially the economic and social impacts of [[colonialism]] and the [[Atlantic slave trade]], Beckles has also had a longstanding involvement with [[Cricket in the West Indies|West Indian cricket]], and has previously served on the board of the [[West Indies Cricket Board]] (WICB). ==Biography== ===Early life=== Beckles was born in Barbados, and began his secondary education at Coleridge and Parry Secondary School in [[Bridgetown]]. He was sent to England to complete his schooling, attending Pitmaston Secondary School and the [[Bournville College|Bournville College of Further Education]] in [[Birmingham]]. Beckles went on to the [[University of Hull]], completing a [[Bachelor of Arts|BA (Hons)]] and [[Doctor of Philosophy|PhD]] with the university's Department of Economic and Social History.[https://web.archive.org/web/20140808055057/http://aswadiaspora.org/candidates09/Beckles.pdf Curriculum vitae of Hilary Beckles] – Association for the Study of the Worldwide African Diaspora. Retrieved 3 January 2013. ===Academic career=== Beckles joined the [[University of West Indies]] as a history lecturer at its campus in [[Mona, Jamaica|Mona]], [[Jamaica]], in 1979, but transferred to its [[Cave Hill campus]] in 1984.[http://www.cavehill.uwi.edu/principal/biography.asp Office of the Principal: Biography] – University of the West Indies. Retrieved 3 January 2013. Having been named a senior research fellow at the [[London]]-based [[Institute of Commonwealth Studies]] in 1986, he was named Chairman of the History Department at UWI in 1992, a role he served in until 1996, and he subsequently served as dean of the Faculty of Humanities from 1994 to 1998. Beckles received a personal professorship in 1993, the university's youngest appointment to the position. His work has covered a variety of areas within the broader topic of [[Afro-Caribbean history]], with works covering early slave rebellions in Barbados, the role of women in the slave trade, and the greater effects of [[colonialism]] on present Barbadian society. Other works have focused more specifically on [[History of Barbados|Barbadian history]], including education, telecommunications, the labour movement, and sporting culture. ===Involvement with cricket=== Having authored several papers and essays on the role of cricket in British West Indian culture, Beckles was the driving force behind the establishment of the Centre for Cricket Research at the Cave Hill campus in 1994, which resulted in the refurbishment of the on-campus [[3Ws Oval]]. Two years later, in 1996, he convinced the [[West Indies Cricket Board]] (WICB) to organise a match between the touring New Zealanders and a team selected by the university's vice-chancellor.[http://sta.uwi.edu/pelican/archives/jj07/vcvpoint.asp VC Viewpoint: Symbols of the West Indian Spirit] – ''The Pelican''. Retrieved 2 January 2013. Matches between touring sides and the Vice Chancellor's XI have since become a regular, almost annual, event.[https://cricketarchive.com/Archive/Teams/1/1335/Other_Matches.html Other matches played by University of West Indies Vice Chancellor's XI] – CricketArchive. Retrieved 2 January 2012.Buchanan-Hind, Elizabeth. [http://sta.uwi.edu/pelican/archives/jj07/article2.asp Tracing the Journey: The Vice Chancellor's XI cricket match] – ''The Pelican''. Retrieved 2 January 2013. In 1999, Beckles published a two-volume series on the history of cricket in the Caribbean, entitled ''The Development of West Indies Cricket''. Three years later, prior to start of the 2002–03 cricket season, the WICB announced that the expanded [[WICB Cup|Red Stripe Bowl]], the premier [[List A cricket|limited-overs]] competition in the West Indies, would feature the [[University of the West Indies cricket team|university's cricket team]]. UWI's two-season stint in the tournament was largely a result of the efforts of Beckles' efforts.Popplewell, Georgia (2004). [http://caribbean-beat.com/issue-66/who%E2%80%99s-really-who-west-indies-cricket Who's Really Who In West Indies Cricket] – ''Caribbean Beat''. Issue 66 (March/April 2004). Retrieved 2 January 2013. He remains a director of what is now the [[C. L. R. James]] Centre for Cricket Research, and is also overall sports coordinator for the university. ==Awards and reputation== Beckles was named "Author of the Year" in 1991 by Barbados Cultural Promotions, and ''We Now Have a Country'', a documentary that he wrote, narrated, and co-directed, was named "Documentary of the Year" in 1993 by the Barbados Association of Journalists. The following year, he was named the inaugural winner of the UWI Vice Chancellor's Award for Excellence in the Field of Research. In 2004, Beckles was awarded an honorary [[Doctor of Letters]] degree by his ''alma mater'', the University of Hull.[http://www2.hull.ac.uk/theuniversity/honorarygraduates.aspx?theme=print Honorary Graduates: A to E] – University of Hull. Retrieved 3 January 2013. He has since received equivalent honorary degrees from the [[Kwame Nkrumah University of Science and Technology]], [[Ghana]], in November 2009,[http://www.ghanaweb.com/GhanaHomePage/NewsArchive/artikel.php?ID=172595 KNUST Crop and Soil Sciences Dept to run PhD programme] – GhanaWeb. Published 27 November 2009. Retrieved 3 January 2013. and from the [[University of Glasgow]], [[Scotland]], in June 2011.[http://www.gla.ac.uk/media/media_196339_en.pdf Honorary Degrees 2011] – University of Glasgow. Retrieved 3 January 2013. In November 2007, Beckles was made a [[Knight or Dame of St. Andrew (Barbados)|Knight of St. Andrew]], the highest honour possible in the [[Order of Barbados]].[http://cheese-on-bread.blogspot.com.au/2007_11_01_archive.html Two new knights for Barbados] – ''Nation News''. Published 30 November 2007. Retrieved 3 January 2013. Some of Beckles' actions, regarding his role in both sports and academics at the university, have been controversial. One commentator has accused him of engaging in the "exploitation of the nation's traditional love of education and qualifications", referring to Beckles' role in the university's development as "empire-building";[https://bajan.wordpress.com/2012/05/31/from-a-native-son-economic-prosperity-is-tied-up-with-improved-education/#more-21442 From a Native Son: Economic Prosperity is Tied up with Improved Education] – Barbados Underground. Published 31 May 2012. Retrieved 3 January 2013. another commentator has criticised his decisions made while on the board of the WICB.Campbell, Junior (2011). [http://www.allvoices.com/contributed-news/10438186-male-bashing-barbados-in-barbados-4-sir-hilary-beckles-bashment Male bashing in Barbados (#4): Sir Hilary Beckles' "bashment"] – All Voices. Published 25 September 2011. Retrieved 3 January 2013. In May 2011, Beckles made a statement suggesting that [[Chris Gayle]] was the "[[Boss (crime)|don]]" of West Indian cricket, comparing him to Jamaican drug lord [[Christopher Coke]] (otherwise known as "Dudus").[http://jamaica-gleaner.com/gleaner/20110522/cleisure/cleisure3.html Beckles Caught In The Slips] – ''[[Gleaner Company|The Gleaner]]''. Published 22 May 2011. Retrieved 3 January 2013.[http://www.zimbio.com/ICC+Cricket+World+Cup+2011/articles/Gs401kBkbEJ/UWI+Cave+Hill+Director+Sir+Hilary+Beckles UWI Cave Hill Director Sir Hilary Beckles Under Fire for Calling Cricket Captain Chris Gayle a "Don" Like "Dudus"] – Zimbio. Published 14 May 2011. Retrieved 3 January 2013. The [[West Indies Players' Association]] (WIPA) subsequently wrote to the WICB and UWI asking for Beckles' dismissal from the board, which did not eventuate.[http://www.jamaicaobserver.com/sports/WIPA-condemns-Beckles-for-comparing-Gayle-to--Dudus- WIPA condemns Beckles for Comparing Chris Gayle with Dudus Coke] – ''[[Jamaica Observer]]''. Published 10 May 2011. Retrieved 3 January 2013. ==Other positions== Beckles serves on the editorial boards of several academic journals, including ''[[William and Mary Quarterly]]'', ''Journal of Caribbean History'', and ''Sports in Society'', and is an international editor for the ''[[Journal of American History]]''. Outside of academia, he has filled the following positions: * Leader of Barbados delegation, [[World Conference against Racism 2001|2001 World Conference Against Racism]] * Director, ICC West Indies Cricket World Cup, Inc. (2005–2007) * Independent Director and Member of Corporate Governance & Ethics Committee, Sagicor Financial Corporation (2005 onwards)[http://investing.businessweek.com/research/stocks/people/person.asp?personId=34513025&ticker=SFI:LN&previousCapId=20385456&previousTitle=Jamaica%20Pegasus%20Ltd. Executive Profile: Hilary McD Beckles B.A. (Hons.) Ph.D.] – ''[[Bloomberg Businessweek]]''. Retrieved 3 January 2013. * Director, [[Sagicor Life]] Jamaica Limited (2006 onwards) * Board member, [[Association for the Study of the Worldwide African Diaspora]] (2013 – 2015){{cite web | url=http://aswadiaspora.org/officers/past-officers/ | title=Past Officers | publisher=ASWAD | accessdate=April 20, 2016}} * Chair, [[CARICOM Reparations Commission]] ==Selected bibliography == * ''Cricket without a Cause: Fall and Rise of the Mighty West Indian Test Cricketers'', Jamaica: Ian Randle Publishers, 2017. {{ISBN|978-9766379605}} * ''Britain's Black Debt: Reparations for Caribbean Slavery and Native Genocide'', University of the West Indies Press, 2012. {{ISBN|978-9766402686}} * ''A History of Barbados: From Amerindian Settlement to Caribbean Single Market'', Cambridge University Press, 2006. {{ISBN|978-0521678490}} * ''Liberties Lost: The Indigenous Caribbean and Slave Systems'', with [[Verene A. Shepherd]], Cambridge University Press, 2004. {{ISBN|978-0521435444}} * ''The Development of West Indies Cricket: The Age of Nationalism'', vol. 1, Pluto Press, 1999. {{ISBN|978-0745314624}} * ''The Development of West Indies Cricket: The Age of Globalization'', vol. 2, Pluto Press, 1999. 978-0745314723 * ''Afro-Caribbean Women and Resistance to Slavery in Barbados'', Karnak House, 1988. {{ISBN|978-0907015260}} ==References== {{Reflist|30em}} {{Authority control}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Beckles, Hilary}} [[Category:1955 births]] [[Category:20th-century historians]] [[Category:21st-century historians]] [[Category:Barbadian academic administrators]] [[Category:Academic journal editors]] [[Category:Barbadian Africanists]] [[Category:Alumni of the University of Hull]] [[Category:Barbadian academics]] [[Category:Barbadian businesspeople]] [[Category:Barbadian cricket administrators]] [[Category:Barbadian educators]] [[Category:Barbadian historians]] [[Category:Barbadian knights]] [[Category:Barbadian male writers]] [[Category:Cricket historians and writers]] [[Category:Cricket players and officials awarded knighthoods]] [[Category:Historians of colonialism]] [[Category:Historians of Colonial North America]] [[Category:Historians of slavery]] [[Category:Historians of the British Empire]] [[Category:Knights and Dames of St Andrew (Barbados)]] [[Category:Living people]] [[Category:University of the West Indies academics]] [[Category:Culture of the African diaspora]] [[Category:20th-century male writers]]

The '''International University in Geneva''' (IUG), founded in 1997, is a [[Foundation (charity)|private]] business school <ref name="Handbook of Universities">[http://www.iun.ch/admin/mediamanager/file.cfm/Handbook_unesco_2013.pdf?contentID=418 Handbook of Universities 2013], UNESCO</ref><ref>{{cite journal |title= International University in Geneva - Undergraduate profile|url=http://www.topuniversities.com/universities/international-university-geneva/undergrad#program|journal=Top universities}}</ref><ref>{{cite journal |title= International University in Geneva|url=http://www.universitieshandbook.com/directory/canton-geneva/international-university-in-geneva|journal=Universities Handbook}}</ref> registered as a not-for-profit Swiss foundation of higher education and located in [[Geneva]], [[Switzerland]].<ref>{{cite journal |title=International University in Geneva|url=http://www.asipes.ch/#!international-university-in-geneva/c11cr|journal=ASIPES|date = 2014}}</ref>
==History == Founded with the aim of providing a multicutural education, it has the status of a not-for-profit Swiss [[Foundation (charity)|Private Foundation]].<ref>{{cite journal |title=A history of reinvention|url=http://www.swissstyle.com/iug/|journal=Swiss Style|date =2016}}</ref> Its first president was David Williamson (former president of [[DuPont]]).<ref>{{cite journal |title=International Geneva Yearbook|url=https://books.google.ch/books?id=UPajsx4prxEC&pg=PA520&lpg=PA520&dq=International+University+in+Geneva+david+williamson&source=bl&ots=1OSx0On1xd&sig=whJGxpjh2O_9lCi-L9UdlmxIjgs&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwiY2Miu97PLAhWkmHIKHarXA30Q6AEIPzAH#v=onepage&q=International%20University%20in%20Geneva%20david%20williamson&f=false|journal=Google Books|date = 2002–2003}}</ref> IUG's mission is to "provide the highest quality education for student success in business and related careers" in "cooperation with the international business community".<ref name="brochure 2014">{{cite web|title=IUG Brochure 2015-17|url=http://issuu.com/anvdesign/docs/international_university_in_geneva__00b5deeee83ba3?e=6761742/11493467}}</ref> The International Herald Tribune called IUG one of "the most international of Switzerland's university level institutions".<ref>Mary Krienke, "International Education in Switzerland", International Herald Tribune, 29–30 March 2003</ref>
IUG counts 270 students.<ref>{{cite journal |title=Member schools Swiss federation of Private Schools|url=http://www.swiss-schools.ch/index.php/en/vsp-mitglieder|journal=Swiss-schools}}</ref>
== Academic programs == The International University in Geneva offers undergraduate and graduate programs such as bachelor's and master's degrees in several disciplines, including [[international relations]], media and [[communications]], computer science, [[business administration]], international management, and [[international trade]].<ref>{{cite journal |title=International University in Geneva|url=http://www.mastersportal.eu/universities/640/international-university-in-geneva.html#tab:why-study-here|journal=Mastersportal}}</ref><ref>{{cite journal |title=World Ranking Guide|url=http://worldranking.blogspot.ch/2010/02/international-university-in-geneva.html|journal=World ranking}}</ref>
A Doctorate in [[Business Administration]] and [[Public Administration]] jointly offered with [[Plymouth University]] is also available.<ref>{{cite journal |title=International Relationships - Institutions|url=http://www1.plymouth.ac.uk/internationalplymouth/relationships/Pages/default.aspx#Switzerland|journal=Plymouth}}</ref>
== Accreditation status == The International University in Geneva has both institutional accreditation and program accreditation. The International University in Geneva is accredited by the [[British Accreditation Council]] (BAC) as an Independent Higher Education Institution. The British Accreditation Council (BAC) is referenced with the European Quality Assurance Register for Higher Education (EQAR). Programs are accredited by the [[ACBSP]] which is recognized by the [[Council on Higher Education Accreditation|CHEA]], and by [[International Assembly for Collegiate Business Education|IACBE]]. Accredited programs are the MBA, the master of Media & Communication, the master of International Management, the master of International Trade, the master of International Relations & Diplomacy as well as bachelor programs in Business Administration, International Relations and Media & Communication.<ref>{{cite journal |title=ACBSP Accredited members|url=http://www.acbsp.org/?page=accredited_members|journal=ACBSP}}</ref><ref>{{cite journal |title=IACBE|url=http://www.iacbe.org/memberpdf/InternationalUniversityinGeneva.pdf|journal=IACBE}}</ref>
International University in Geneva is not accredited by the Swiss [[Swiss Center of Accreditation and Quality Assurance in Higher Education|OAQ]], indicating the institution is not recognized as state university in Switzerland.<ref>{{cite journal|title=CRUS Recognized or Accredited Swiss Higher Education Institutions|url=http://www.crus.ch/information-programme/recognition-swiss-enic/recognised-or-accredited-swiss-higher-education-institutions.html|journal=CRUS}}</ref>
The International University in Geneva is referenced as an accredited institution on the [[World Higher Education Database]] (WHED) of the [[International Association of Universities]] (IAU).{{cn|date=August 2017}}
== Rankings == In 2017 [[Eduniversal]] ranked IUG as an "excellent" business school, amongst the 1000 best in the world and the seventh best school in Switzerland, based on international influence and recognition.<ref>{{cite journal |title=Eduniversal ranking|url=http://www.eduniversal-ranking.com/search/country/switzerland|journal=Eduniversal}}</ref>
== People == The president is Eric Willumsen (founder and executive vice-president).<ref>{{cite journal |title=Zoominfo Eric Willumsen|url=http://www.zoominfo.com/p/Eric-Willumsen/54680901|journal=Zoominfo}}</ref> The chancellor is Claude Martin, former [[Director-general|Director General]] of [[World Wide Fund for Nature]].<ref>{{cite journal|title=Full Member|url=http://www.clubofrome.org/?p=802|journal=Club of Rome|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140306094333/http://www.clubofrome.org/?p=802|archivedate=2014-03-06|df=}}</ref>
Faculty members have earned degrees at [[London Business School]], [[Cranfield]], [[Harvard Law School|HLS]], [[International Institute for Management Development|IMD]], [[INSEAD]], [[Sorbonne]], [[University of California, Berkeley|Berkeley]], and work at [[United Nations]] agencies, [[NGOs]], and other [[multinational companies]].{{Citation needed|date=February 2014}}
Guest speakers and honorary doctors for the graduation ceremony have included [[Adolf Ogi]], [[Queen Noor of Jordan]], [[Sir Peter Alexander Ustinov]], [[Bertrand Piccard]], [[Edward de Bono]], [[Daniel Borel]], [[Albert II, Prince of Monaco]],<ref>{{cite journal |title=Prince Albert 2 of Monaco, awarded an Honorary Doctorate IUG|url=http://divainternational.ch/spip.php?article382|journal=Divainternational}}</ref> Patrick Odier, [[Sepp Blatter]], Werner Geissler from [[Procter & Gamble]], and former [[IOC]] Director General François Carrard.<ref>{{cite journal |title=Top Swiss University in International Business Education IUG|url=http://www.petersons.com/college-search/international-university-in-geneva-000_10000047.aspx|journal=Petersons}}</ref>
== Exchange programmes == IUG has developed educational affiliation agreements for study-abroad in Europe including [[ESIC]] Madrid in Spain, [[Metropolia University of Applied Sciences]] [[Helsinki]] in [[Finland]], [[Institut supérieur du commerce de Paris|Institut Supérieur du Commerce]] [[Paris]] in [[France]] and [[Yeditepe University]] [[Istanbul]] in [[Turkey]].
IUG developed educational affiliation agreements for study-abroad in North and South America including [[Tulane University|Tulane]] in [[New Orleans]], [[Indiana University of Pennsylvania|IUP]] in [[Pennsylvania]], [[Monterey Institute of International Studies|MIIS]] in [[California]], [[University of Connecticut|UConn]] in [[Connecticut]], [[Champlain College]] in [[Vermont]], [[Anahuac University]] in [[Mexico City]], [[Universidad Externado de Colombia]] in [[Colombia]] and Universidad de San Ignacio de Loyola in [[Peru]].
Finally IUG also developed affiliation agreements for study-abroad in Asia with the [[IIFT|Indian Institute of Foreign Trade]], [[New Delhi]] - [[India]].<ref>{{cite journal |title=Les formations internationales en Suisse|url=http://www.studyrama.ch/spip.php?article612|journal=Studyrama}}</ref><ref>{{cite journal |title=International Network|url=http://www.iun.ch/en-en/about-iug/international-network|journal=IUN}}</ref>

{{globalize/US|date=September 2014}} An '''international monetary system''' is a set of internationally agreed rules, conventions and supporting institutions that facilitate [[international trade]], [[Foreign direct investment|cross border investment]] and generally the [[redistribution (economics)|reallocation of capital]] between [[nation state]]s. It should provide means of payment acceptable to buyers and sellers of different nationalities, including deferred payment. To operate successfully, it needs to inspire confidence, to provide sufficient liquidity for fluctuating levels of trade, and to provide means by which global imbalances can be corrected. The system can grow organically as the collective result of numerous individual agreements between international economic factors spread over several decades. Alternatively, it can arise from a single architectural vision, as happened at [[United Nations Monetary and Financial Conference|Bretton Woods]] in 1944.
==Historical overview== {{See also|Reserve currency}} Throughout history, precious metals such as [[gold]] and [[silver]] have been used for trade, sometimes in the form of [[bullion]], and from early history the coins of various issuers – generally kingdoms and empires – have been traded. The earliest known records of pre-coinage use of precious metals for monetary exchange are from Mesopotamia and Egypt, dating from the third millennium BC.<ref name = "money a history" >{{cite book | editor= Jonathan Williams with Joe Cribb and Elizabeth Errington | title = Money a History | year = 1997 | ISBN = 0-7141-0885-5 | pages = 16–27 , 111 ,127 , 131 , 136 , 136 , | publisher = British Museum Press}}</ref> Early money took many forms, apart from bullion; for instance bronze [[spade money]] which became common in [[Zhou dynasty]] China in the late 7th century BC. At that time, forms of money were also developed in [[Lydia]] in [[Asia Minor]], from where its use spread to nearby Greek cities and later to many other places.<ref name = "money a history" />
Sometimes formal [[monetary system]]s have been imposed by regional rulers. For example, scholars have tentatively suggested that the Roman king [[Servius Tullius]] created a primitive monetary system in the early history of [[Ancient Rome|Rome]]. Tullius reigned in the sixth century BC - several centuries before Rome is believed to have developed a formal coinage system.<ref>{{cite book | last = Raaflaub | first = Kurt | title = Social Struggles in Archaic Rome | year = 2005 | ISBN = 1-4051-0061-3 | pages = 59–60 | publisher =WileyBlackwell}}</ref>
As with bullion, early use of coinage is believed to have been generally the preserve of the elite. But by about the 4th century BC coins were widely used in Greek cities. They were generally supported by the city state authorities, who endeavoured to ensure they retained their values regardless of fluctuations in the availability of whatever base or precious metals they were made from.<ref name = "money a history" /> From Greece the use of coins spread slowly westwards throughout Europe, and eastwards to India. Coins were in use in India from about 400 BC; initially they played a greater role in religion than in trade, but by the 2nd century{{clarify|date=August 2018}} they had become central to commercial transactions. Monetary systems that were developed in India were so successful that they spread through parts of Asia well into the Middle Ages.<ref name = "money a history" />
As a variety of coins became common within a region, they were exchanged by [[moneychanger]]s, the predecessors of today's [[foreign exchange market]], as mentioned in the Biblical story of [[Jesus and the money changers]]. In Venice and the other Italian city states of the early Middle Ages, money changers would often have to struggle to perform calculations involving six or more currencies. This partly led to [[Fibonacci]] writing his [[Liber Abaci]] which popularised the use of [[Arabic numerals|Indo-Arabic numerals]], which displaced the more difficult Roman numerals then in use by western merchants.<ref name="Ascent "> {{cite web |title=The Ascent of Money , episode 1 |publisher=PBS |url=https://www.pbs.org/wnet/ascentofmoney/ }} </ref>
[[File:International money montage.jpg|thumb|left| Historic international currencies. From top left: crystalline [[gold]], a 5th-century BCE [[Persian daric]], an 8th-century English [[mancus]], and an 18th-century [[Spanish real]].]] When a given nation or empire has achieved regional [[hegemony]], its currency has been a basis for international trade, and hence for a ''de facto'' monetary system. In the West – Europe and the Middle East – an early such coin was the [[Persian daric]]. This was succeeded by [[Roman currency]] of the [[Roman Empire]], such as the [[denarius]], then the [[Gold Dinar]] of the Ottoman Empire, and later – from the 16th to 20th centuries, during the [[Age of Imperialism]] – by the currency of European colonial powers: the [[Spanish dollar]], the [[Dutch guilder]], the [[French franc]] and the [[British pound sterling]]; at times one currency has been pre-eminent, at times no one dominated. With the growth of American power, the [[US dollar]] became the basis for the international monetary system, formalised in the [[Bretton Woods system|Bretton Woods]] agreement that established the post–World War II monetary order, with fixed exchange rates of other currencies to the dollar, and [[convertibility]] of the dollar into gold. The Bretton Woods system broke down, culminating in the [[Nixon shock]] of 1971, ending convertibility; but the US dollar has remained the ''de facto'' basis of the world monetary system, though no longer ''de jure''{{dubious|date=August 2018}}, with various European currencies and the [[Japanese yen]] also being prominent in foreign exchange markets. Since the formation of the [[Euro]], the Euro has also gained use as a [[reserve currency]] and a medium of transactions, though the dollar has remained the most important currency.
A dominant currency may be used directly or indirectly by other nations: for example, English kings minted the gold [[mancus]], presumably to function as dinars to exchange with [[Islamic Spain]]; colonial powers sometimes minted coins that resembled those already used in a distant territory; and more recently, a number of nations have used the US dollar as their local currency, a custom called [[dollarization]].
Until the 19th century, the global monetary system was loosely linked at best, with Europe, the Americas, India and China (among others) having largely separate economies, and hence monetary systems were regional. [[European colonization of the Americas]], starting with the Spanish empire, led to the integration of American and European economies and monetary systems, and European colonization of Asia led to the dominance of European currencies, notably the British pound sterling in the 19th century, succeeded by the US dollar in the 20th century. Some, such as [[Michael Hudson (economist)|Michael Hudson]], foresee the decline of a single base for the global monetary system, and the emergence instead of regional [[trade bloc]]s; he cites the emergence of the Euro as an example. See also [[Global financial system]]s, [[world-systems approach]] and [[polarity in international relations]]. It was in the later half of the 19th century that a monetary system with close to universal global participation emerged, based on the gold standard.
==History of modern global monetary orders==
===The pre WWI financial order: 1816–1919=== {{Main|Gold Standard#Establishment of the international gold standard}}
[[File:Gold Bars.jpg|thumb|The [[gold standard]] widely adopted in this era rested on the conversion of paper notes into pre-set quantities of gold.]] From the 1816 to the outbreak of World War I in 1914, the world benefited from a well-integrated financial order, sometimes known as the "first age of globalisation".<ref name = "GPE">{{cite book | last = Ravenhill | first = John | title = Global Political Economy | year = 2005 | pages = 7, 328 | publisher =Oxford University Press}}</ref> <ref>Occasionally also called the ''golden age of capitalism'' in older sources, and also the ''first golden age of capitalism'' in later sources that recognise golden age that spanned approx 1951–73. A few economists such as [[Barry Eichengreen]] date the ''first age of globalisation'' as starting in the early 1860s with the laying of the first transatlantic cables between Great Britain and the USA.</ref> There were monetary unions which enabled member countries to accept each others' currencies as legal tender. Such unions included the [[Latin Monetary Union]] (Belgium, Italy, Switzerland, France) and the [[Scandinavian monetary union]] (Denmark, Norway and Sweden). In the absence of shared membership of a union, transactions were facilitated by widespread participation in the [[gold standard]], by both independent nations and their colonies. Great Britain was at the time the world's pre-eminent financial, imperial, and industrial power, ruling more of the world and exporting more capital as a percentage of her national income than any other creditor nation has since.<ref>{{cite book |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=SnXDHXz-DPQC&dq=The+end+of+globalization:+lessons+from+the+great+depression&printsec=frontcover&source=bn&hl=en&ei=ANm8SZChN9TIjAeEj5WTCA&sa=X&oi=book_result&resnum=4&ct=result#PPA12,M1 |title= The End of Globalization |publisher= Harvard University Press / Google books |author= Harold James |page = 12 |accessdate=2009-03-17}}</ref>
While capital controls comparable to the Bretton Woods system were not in place, damaging capital flows were far less common than they were to be in the post 1971 era. In fact Great Britain's capital exports helped to correct global imbalances as they tended to be counter-cyclical, rising when Britain's economy went into recession, thus compensating other states for income lost from export of goods.<ref>{{cite book | last = Helleiner | first = Eirc | editor = John Ravenhill | title = Global Political Economy | year = 2005 | chapter = 6 | page = 154 | publisher =Oxford University Press}}</ref> Accordingly, this era saw mostly steady growth and a relatively low level of financial crises. In contrast to the Bretton Woods system, the pre–World War I financial order was not created at a single high level conference; rather it evolved organically in a series of discrete steps. The [[Gilded Age]], a time of especially rapid development in North America, falls into this period.
===Between the World Wars: 1919–1939=== [[File:Lange-MigrantMother02.jpg|thumb|left|This era saw periods of worldwide economic hardship. The image is [[Dorothea Lange]]'s ''[[Migrant Mother]]'' depiction of destitute [[pea-pickers]] in [[California]], taken in March 1936.]] The years between the world wars have been described as a period of "de-globalisation", as both international trade and capital flows shrank compared to the period before World War I. During World War I, countries had abandoned the gold standard. Except for the United States, they later returned to it only briefly. By the early 1930s, the prevailing order was essentially a fragmented system of floating exchange rates.<ref>{{cite book | last = Helleiner | first = Eirc | editor = John Ravenhill | title = Global Political Economy | year = 2005 | chapter= 6 | page = 156 | publisher =Oxford University Press}} </ref> In this era, the experience of Great Britain and others was that the gold standard ran counter to the need to retain domestic policy autonomy. To protect their reserves of gold, countries would sometimes need to raise interest rates and generally follow a deflationary policy. The greatest need for this could arise in a downturn, just when leaders would have preferred to lower rates to encourage growth. Economist Nicholas Davenport <ref>{{cite book | last = Skidelsky | first = Robert | title = ''John Maynard Keynes: 1883-1946: Economist,Philosopher, Statesman'' | year = 2003 |page = 346 | chapter = 22 |publisher =McMillan }}</ref> had even argued that the wish to return Britain to the gold standard "sprang from a sadistic desire by the Bankers to inflict pain on the British working class."
By the end of World War I, Great Britain was heavily indebted to the United States, allowing the USA to largely displace it as the world's foremost financial power. The United States, however, was reluctant to assume Great Britain's leadership role, partly due to isolationist influences and a focus on domestic concerns. In contrast to Great Britain in the previous era, capital exports from the US were not countercyclical. They expanded rapidly with the United States' economic growth in the 1920s until 1928, but then almost completely halted as the US economy began slowing in that year. As the [[Great Depression]] intensified in 1930, financial institutions were hit hard along with trade; in 1930 alone, 1345 US banks collapsed. <ref>{{cite book |url= https://books.google.com/books?id=qpIJuv5n3p0C&dq=Aspects+of+European+history,+1789-1980&printsec=frontcover&source=bl&ots=usU_4oC0Gs&sig=qOMQmkIb-vLVrONfMW6b9A3I3zE&hl=en&ei=Ley8SbFKjMiMB_T35aMI&sa=X&oi=book_result&resnum=3&ct=result |title= Aspects of European history, 1789-1980 |publisher= Routledge / Google books |author= Stephen J. Lee |page = 135 |accessdate=2009-03-17}} </ref> During the 1930s, the United States raised trade barriers, refused to act as an international [[lender of last resort]], and refused calls to cancel war debts, all of which further aggravated economic hardship for other countries. According to economist [[John Maynard Keynes]], another factor contributing to the turbulent economic performance of this era was the insistence of French premier [[Georges Clemenceau|Clemenceau]] that Germany pay [[World War I reparations|war reparations]] at too high a level, which Keynes described in his book [[The Economic Consequences of the Peace]].
===The Bretton Woods Era: 1944–1973=== {{Main|Bretton Woods system}} [[File:WhiteandKeynes.jpg|thumb|right|250px|[[Harry Dexter White]] (left) and [[John Maynard Keynes]] (right) at [[Bretton Woods Conference|Bretton Woods]]]]
British and American policy makers began to plan the post-war international monetary system in the early 1940s. The objective was to create an order that combined the benefits of an integrated and relatively liberal international system with the freedom for governments to pursue domestic policies aimed at promoting full employment and social wellbeing.<ref>{{cite book | last = Helleiner | first = Eric | title = States and the reemergence of global finance | year = 1996 | chapter= 2: Bretton Woods and the Endorsement of Capital Controls | publisher =Cornell University Press}}</ref> The principal architects of the new system, John Maynard Keynes and [[Harry Dexter White]], created a plan which was endorsed by the 42 countries attending the 1944 [[United Nations Monetary and Financial Conference|Bretton Woods conference]], formally known as the [[United Nations]] Monetary and Financial Conference. The plan involved nations agreeing to a system of fixed but adjustable{{clarify|date=August 2018}} exchange rates so that the currencies were pegged against the dollar, with the dollar itself convertible into gold. So in effect this was a gold – dollar exchange standard. There were a number of improvements on the old gold standard. Two international institutions, the [[International Monetary Fund]] (IMF) and the [[World Bank]] were created. A key part of their function was to replace private finance as a more reliable source of lending for investment projects in developing states. At the time the soon to be defeated powers of Germany and Japan were envisaged as states soon to be in need of such development, and there was a desire from both the US and Britain not to see the defeated powers saddled with punitive sanctions that would inflict lasting pain on future generations. The new exchange rate system allowed countries facing economic hardship to devalue their currencies by up to 10% against the dollar (more if approved by the IMF) – thus they would not be forced to undergo deflation to stay in the gold standard. A system of capital controls was introduced to protect countries from the damaging effects of capital flight and to allow countries to pursue independent macro economic policies <ref>According to Keynes: "In my view the whole management of the domestic economy depends on being free to have the appropriate rate of interest without reference to rates prevailing elsewhere in the world. Capital control is a corollary to this" </ref> while still welcoming flows intended for productive investment. Keynes had argued against the dollar having such a central role in the monetary system, and suggested an international currency called [[bancor]] be used instead, but he was overruled by the Americans. Towards the end of the Bretton Woods era, the central role of the dollar became a problem as international demand eventually forced the US to run a persistent trade deficit, which undermined confidence in the dollar. This, together with the emergence of a parallel market for gold in which the price soared above the official US mandated price, led to speculators running down the US gold reserves. Even when convertibility was restricted to nations only, some, notably France,<ref name = "Copeland"> {{cite book |author = Laurence Copeland |title= Exchange Rates and International Finance |edition= 4th |pages = 10–35 |isbn=0-273-68306-3 |publisher= Prentice Hall }}</ref> continued building up hoards of gold at the expense of the US. Eventually these pressures caused [[Richard Nixon|President Nixon]] to end all convertibility into gold on 15 August 1973. This event marked the effective end of the Bretton Woods system; attempts were made to find other mechanisms to preserve the fixed exchange rates over the next few years, but they were not successful, resulting in a system of floating exchange rates.<ref name = "Copeland"/>
===The post Bretton Woods system: 1973– present=== {{Main|Washington Consensus}} [[File:NYC NYSE.jpg|thumb|left|The [[New York Stock Exchange]]. The current era has seen huge and turbulent flows of capital between nations.]]
An alternative name for the post Bretton Woods system is the '''Washington Consensus'''. While the name was coined in 1989, the associated economic system came into effect years earlier: according to economic historian [[Robert Skidelsky|Lord Skidelsky]] the ''Washington Consensus'' is generally seen as spanning 1980–2009 (the latter half of the 1970s being a transitional period).<ref name = "return"> {{cite book |author= [[Robert Skidelsky]] |title= Keynes: The return of the Master |year= 2009 |pages = 116–126 |isbn= 978-1-84614-258-1 |publisher= Allen Lane }}</ref> The transition away from Bretton Woods was marked by a [[Post-war displacement of Keynesianism|switch]] from a state led to a market led system.<ref name="GPE"/> The Bretton Wood system is considered by economic historians to have broken down in the 1970s:<ref name = "return"/> crucial events being [[Richard Nixon#Economy|Nixon suspending the dollar's convertibility into gold]] in 1973, the United States' abandonment of capital controls in 1974, and the UK's ending of capital controls in 1979 which was swiftly copied by most other major economies.
In some parts of the developing world, liberalisation brought significant benefits for large sections of the population – most prominently with [[Deng Xiaoping]]'s [[Economic reforms in China|reforms in China]] since 1978 and the liberalisation of India after its [[1991 India economic crisis|1991 crisis]].
Generally the industrial nations experienced much slower growth and higher unemployment than in the previous era, and according to Professor Gordon Fletcher in retrospect the 1950s and 60s when the Bretton Woods system was operating came to be seen as a [[Golden Age of Capitalism|golden age]]. <ref>{{cite book | last = Fletcher | first = Gordon | title = The Keynesian Revolution and Its Critics: Issues of Theory and Policy for the Monetary Production Economy | year = 1989 | chapter = Introduction | pages = xx |publisher= Palgrave MacMillan }} </ref> Financial crises have been more intense and have increased in frequency by about 300% – with the damaging effects prior to 2008 being chiefly felt in the emerging economies. On the positive side, at least until 2008 investors have frequently achieved very high rates of return, with salaries and bonuses in the financial sector reaching record levels.
====The "Revived Bretton Woods system" identified in 2003==== {| class="wikitable" style="font-size:98%; text-align:center;" align="right" |+ '''International monetary systems over two centuries'''<ref>Source: International Monetary Reform 2011 [http://robertmundell.net/ebooks/free-downloads/ robertmundell.net]: Presentation at the China G-20 Seminar, Nanjing PRC, March 31, 2011 by [[Robert Mundell]]</ref> |- bgcolor="background:#eee;" ! Leaders |- | align="left"| 1803–1873 || [[Bimetallism]] || [[Gold]], [[silver]] || [[France]], [[United Kingdom|UK]] |- | align="left"| 1873–1914 || [[Gold standard]] || [[Gold]], [[Pound sterling|pound]] || [[United Kingdom|UK]] |- | align="left"| 1914–1924 || [[United States dollar|Anchored dollar standard]] || [[Gold]], [[United States dollar|dollar]] || [[United States|US]], [[United Kingdom|UK]], [[France]] |- | align="left"| 1924–1933 || [[Gold standard]] || [[Gold]], [[United States dollar|dollar]], [[Pound sterling|pound]] || [[United States|US]], [[United Kingdom|UK]], [[France]] |- | align="left"| 1933–1971 || [[United States dollar|Anchored dollar standard]] || [[Gold]], [[United States dollar|dollar]] || [[United States|US]], [[Group of Ten (economic)|G-10]] |- | align="left"| 1971–1973 || [[United States dollar|Dollar standard]] || [[United States dollar|Dollar]] || [[United States|US]] |- | align="left"| 1973–1985 || [[Exchange rate regime|Flexible exchange rates]] || [[United States dollar|Dollar]], [[Deutsche Mark|mark]], [[Pound sterling|pound]] || [[United States|US]], [[Germany]], [[Japan]] |- | align="left"| 1985–1999 || [[Exchange rate regime|Managed exchange rates]] || [[United States dollar|Dollar]], [[Deutsche Mark|mark]], [[Japanese yen|yen]] || [[United States|US]], [[G8|G7]], [[International Monetary Fund|IMF]] |- | align="left"| 1999- || [[United States dollar|Dollar]], [[euro]] || [[United States dollar|Dollar]], [[euro]], [[Japanese yen|yen]] || [[United States|US]], [[Eurozone]], [[International Monetary Fund|IMF]] |} From 2004, economists such as Michael P. Dooley, Peter M. Garber, and David Folkerts-Landau began writing papers describing the emergence of a new international system involving an interdependency between states with generally high savings in Asia lending and exporting to western states with generally high spending.<ref>{{cite journal |first=Michael P. |last=Dooley |first2=David |last2=Folkerts‐Landau |first3=Peter |last3=Garber |title=The Revived Bretton Woods System |journal=International Journal of Finance and Economics |volume=9 |issue=4 |pages=307–313 |year=2004 |doi=10.1002/ijfe.250 }}</ref> Similar to the original ''Bretton Woods'', this included Asian currencies being pegged to the dollar, though this time by the unilateral intervention of Asian governments in the currency market to stop their currencies appreciating. The developing world as a whole stopped running current account deficits in 1999 <ref>{{cite book | last = Wolf | first = Martin | title = Fixing Global Finance | year = 2009 | chapter= 3 | page = 39 | publisher =Yale University Press}}</ref> – widely seen as a response to unsympathetic treatment following the [[1997 Asian Financial Crisis]]. The most striking example of east-west interdependency is the relationship between China and America, which [[Niall Ferguson]] calls [[Chimerica]]. From 2004, This supposed "New Bretton Woods",<ref>*[[Robert Brenner]], "What is Good for Goldman Sachs is Good for America The Origins of the Present Crisis" (October 2, 2009). Center for Social Theory and Comparative History. Paper 2009-1. [http://repositories.cdlib.org/cstch/2009-1], p 14f. </ref> as a "fiction", and called for the elimination of the structural imbalances that underlie it, viz, the chronic US current account deficit.<ref>[http://www.pimco.com/LeftNav/Viewpoints/2007/Renegade+Economics.htm Renegade Economics: The Bretton Woods II Fiction], by Chris P. Dialynas and Marshall Auerback, PIMCO</ref>
However, since at least 2007 those authors have also called for a new ''de jure'' system: for key international financial institutions like the IMF and World Bank to be revamped to meet the demands of the current age,<ref>{{cite web |url=http://ideas.repec.org/p/nbr/nberwo/13197.html |title=The Two Crises of International Economics |author1=Michael P. Dooley |author2=David Folkerts-Landau |author3=Peter Garber |publisher=[[National Bureau of Economic Research]] |date=June 2007}}</ref> and between 2008 and mid-2009 the term ''New Bretton Woods'' was increasingly used in the latter sense. By late 2009, with less emphases on structural reform to the international monetary system and more attention being paid to issues such as [[Balance of payments|re-balancing]] the world economy.
Since 2011, [[Sanjeev Sanyal]], a colleague of Dooley, Garber and Folkerts-Landau has taken the framework a step further to argue that periods of global economic expansions are almost always underpinned by symbiotic imbalances. Such imbalances cause distortions but are an inevitable part of expanding economic ecosystems. Thus, he argues that the next round of economic growth will again be underpinned by a return to global imbalances, probably with China supplying capital and the US again running deficits to absorb it. He names this relationship Bretton Woods III.<ref>http://www.project-syndicate.org/commentary/global-economy-imbalances-by-sanjeev-sanyal-2014-11</ref>
==Calls for a "New Bretton Woods"== [[File:Cumbre de Washington.jpg|thumb|250px|G-20 leaders at [[2008 G-20 Washington summit|Summit on Financial Markets and the World Economy]].]] Leading financial journalist [[Martin Wolf]] has reported that all financial crises since 1971 have been preceded by large [[Capital account|capital inflows]] into affected regions. While ever since the seventies there have been numerous calls from the [[global justice movement]] for a revamped international system to tackle the problem of unfettered capital flows, it was not until late 2008 that this idea began to receive substantial support from leading politicians. On September 26, 2008, [[Nicolas Sarkozy|French President Nicolas Sarkozy]], then also the [[President of the European Union]], said, "We must rethink the financial system from scratch, as at Bretton Woods."<ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.eurodad.org/whatsnew/articles.aspx?id=2988 |title=Senior figures call for new Bretton Woods ahead of Bank/Fund meetings |author1=George Parker |author2=Tony Barber |author3=Daniel Dombey |date=October 9, 2008 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20081014072859/http://www.eurodad.org/whatsnew/articles.aspx?id=2988 |archivedate=October 14, 2008 |df= }}</ref>
On October 13, 2008, British Prime Minister [[Gordon Brown]] <ref>{{cite web |url = http://afp.google.com/article/ALeqM5iqbjATskwxNr2tyDViM7bbz8J_rg |title = World needs new Bretton Woods, says Brown |author = Agence France-Presse (AFP) |date = October 13, 2008 |deadurl = yes |archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20081018193748/http://afp.google.com/article/ALeqM5iqbjATskwxNr2tyDViM7bbz8J_rg |archivedate = October 18, 2008 |df = }}</ref> said world leaders must meet to agree to a new economic system: {{cquote| We must have a new Bretton Woods, building a new international financial architecture for the years ahead. }} However, Brown's approach was quite different from the original [[Bretton Woods system]], emphasising the continuation of [[globalization]] and [[free trade]] as opposed to a return to fixed exchange rates.<ref>{{cite web |url = http://www.egovmonitor.com/node/21484 |title = PM's Speech on the Global Economy |publisher = eGov monitor |author = [[Gordon Brown]] |date = October 13, 2008 |deadurl = yes |archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20090911034637/http://www.egovmonitor.com/node/21484 |archivedate = September 11, 2009 |df = }}</ref> There were tensions between Brown and Sarkozy, who argued that the "Anglo-Saxon" model of unrestrained markets had failed.<ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/worldnews/europe/france/3205033/Gordon-Browns-Bretton-Woods-summit-call-risks-spat-with-Nicholas-Sarkozy.html |title=Gordon Brown's Bretton Woods summit call risks spat with Nicholas Sarkozy |publisher=[[The Daily Telegraph]]|author1=James Kirkup |author2=Bruno Waterfield |date=2008-10-17 |accessdate=2008-11-16 | location=London }}</ref> However European leaders were united in calling for a "Bretton Woods II" summit to redesign the world's financial architecture.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.ft.com/cms/s/0/7cc16b54-9b19-11dd-a653-000077b07658.html |title=European call for 'Bretton Woods II' |publisher=[[Financial Times]] |date=2008-10-16 |accessdate=2009-03-17 }}</ref> President Bush was agreeable to the calls, and the resulting meeting was the [[2008 G-20 Washington summit]]. International agreement was achieved for the common adoption of Keynesian fiscal stimulus,<ref>{{cite web |url= http://www.ft.com/cms/s/0/c4cf37f4-d611-11dd-a9cc-000077b07658.html |title= The undeniable shift to Keynes |publisher= The Financial Times |author= Chris Giles in London, Ralph Atkins in Frankfurt and,Krishna Guha in Washington |accessdate=2009-01-23}} </ref> an area where the US and China were to emerge as the world's leading actors.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.ft.com/cms/s/0/63165076-7bcd-11de-9772-00144feabdc0.htm |title=US and China display united economic stance |publisher=[[Financial Times]] |date=2009-07-29 |accessdate=2009-08-05 }}</ref> Yet there was no substantial progress towards reforming the international financial system, and nor was there at the 2009 meeting of the World Economic Forum at Davos <ref>{{cite web |url= http://www.ft.com/cms/s/4a44f222-f221-11dd-9678-0000779fd2ac.html |title= Why Davos Man is waiting for Obama to save him |publisher= The Financial Times |author= Martin Wolf |accessdate=2008-02-12}} </ref>
Despite this lack of results leaders continued to campaign for ''Bretton Woods II''. [[Italy|Italian]] Economics Minister [[Giulio Tremonti]] said that Italy would use its 2009 [[G7]] chairmanship to push for a "New Bretton Woods." He had been critical of the U.S.'s response to the [[global financial crisis of 2008]], and had suggested that the dollar may be superseded as the base currency of the Bretton Woods system.<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.reuters.com/article/euMergersNews/idUSLG34287520081016 |title=Italy queries dollar's role in Bretton Woods reform |date=2008-10-16 |accessdate=2008-11-16 |publisher=[[Reuters]] }}</ref> <ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.forbes.com/home/2008/10/16/europe-summit-investors-update-markets-equity-cx_po_mlm_1016markets39.html|author1=Parmy Olson |author2=Miriam Marcus |title=Bringing The Banking Mess To Broadway |publisher=[[Forbes]] |date=2008-10-16 |accessdate=2008-11-16 }}</ref> <ref>{{cite news |url = http://us.ft.com/ftgateway/superpage.ft?news_id=fto100920081302015280 |title = Giulio Tremonti: A critic demands a new Bretton Woods |author = Guy Dinmore |publisher = [[Financial Times]] |date = 2008-10-08 |accessdate = 2008-11-16 |deadurl = yes |archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20090506143404/http://us.ft.com/ftgateway/superpage.ft?news_id=fto100920081302015280 |archivedate = 2009-05-06 |df = }}</ref>
[[Instituto_del_Tercer_Mundo#Choike|Choike]], a portal organisation representing Southern Hemisphere [[NGO]]s, called for the establishment of "international permanent and binding mechanisms of control over capital flows" and as of March 2009 had achieved over 550 signatories from civil society organisations. <ref>{{cite web |url= http://www.choike.org/campaigns/camp.php?5 |title= Let’s put finance in its place! |publisher= Choike |author= various - including Action Aid, War on Want, World Council of Churches |accessdate=2009-03-18}} </ref> {| class="wikitable" style="font-size:98%; text-align:center;" align="left" |+ '''Competing ideas for the next international monetary system''' |- bgcolor="background:#eee;" ! System !! Reserve assets !! Leaders |- | [[Exchange rate regime|Flexible exchange rates]]<ref>{{cite web|url=https://foreignpolicy.com/articles/2011/09/07/the_new_triumvirate |title=The New Triumvirate |publisher=Foreign Policy |author=Mansoor Dailami |date=September 7, 2011}}</ref> || [[United States dollar|Dollar]], [[euro]], [[renminbi]] || [[United States|US]], [[Eurozone]], [[People's Republic of China|China]] |- | [[Special drawing rights|Special drawing rights standard]]<ref>{{cite web|url=https://foreignpolicy.com/articles/2011/09/07/dreaming_of_sdrs |title=Dreaming of SDRs |publisher=Foreign Policy |author=David Bosco |date=September 7, 2011}}</ref> || [[Special drawing rights|SDR]] || [[United States|US]], [[G-20 major economies|G-20]], [[International Monetary Fund|IMF]] |- | [[Gold standard]]<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.cnbc.com/id/44356270 |title=Gold standard comeback enjoys support |publisher=CNBC |author=Jessica Naziri |date=September 1, 2011}}</ref> || [[Gold]], [[United States dollar|dollar]] || [[United States|US]] |- | [[2012 BRICS summit|Delhi Declaration]]<ref>{{cite web|url=http://mea.gov.in/mystart.php?id=190019162 |title=Fourth BRICS Summit - Delhi Declaration |publisher=Indian Ministry of External Affairs |date=March 29, 2012}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://blogs.ft.com/beyond-brics/2011/04/14/guest-post-rupee-can-serve-as-a-reserve-currency-too/ |title=Guest post: Rupee can serve as a reserve currency too |publisher=Financial Times |author=Mitul Kotecha |date=April 14, 2011}}</ref> || [[Currency basket]] || [[BRICS]] |} March 2009 saw Gordon Brown continuing to advocate for reform and the granting of extended powers to international financial institutions like the IMF at the April G20 summit in London, <ref>{{cite news |url= https://www.telegraph.co.uk/finance/financetopics/davos/4398124/Gordon-Brown-warns-of-void-left-by-collapse-of-global-financial-system.html |title= Gordon Brown warns of void left by collapse of global financial system |publisher= The Daily Telegraph |author= Edmund Conway |accessdate=2009-03-17 | location=London | date=2009-01-30}}</ref> and was said to have president Obama's support .<ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.ft.com/cms/s/0/83bf93e0-085b-11de-8a33-0000779fd2ac.html |title=Brown wins Obama's support for a shake-up of global regulation |author1=George Parker |author2=Andrew Ward in Washington |publisher=[[Financial Times]] |date=2009-03-04 |accessdate=2009-03-17}}</ref> Also during March 2009, in a speech entitled ''Reform the International Monetary System'', [[Zhou Xiaochuan]], the governor of the [[People's Bank of China]] came out in favour of Keynes's idea of a centrally managed global reserve currency. Dr Zhou argued that it was unfortunate that part of the reason for the Bretton Woods system breaking down was the failure to adopt Keynes's [[bancor]]. Dr Zhou said that national currencies were unsuitable for use as global reserve currencies as a result of the [[Triffin dilemma]] – the difficulty faced by reserve currency issuers in trying to simultaneously achieve their domestic monetary policy goals and meet other countries' demand for reserve currency. Dr Zhou proposed a gradual move towards increased use of IMF [[special drawing rights]] (SDRs) as a centrally managed global reserve currency <ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.ft.com/cms/s/0/7851925a-17a2-11de-8c9d-0000779fd2ac.html |title=China calls for new reserve currency |author=Jamil Anderlini in Beijing |publisher=[[Financial Times]] |date=2009-03-23 |accessdate=2009-04-13}}</ref> <ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.pbc.gov.cn/english/detail.asp?col=6500&id=178 |title=Reform the International Monetary System |author=[[Zhou Xiaochuan]] |publisher=[[People's Bank of China]] |date=2009-03-23 |accessdate=2009-04-13 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090327070907/http://www.pbc.gov.cn/english/detail.asp?col=6500&ID=178 |archivedate=March 27, 2009 |df= }}</ref> His proposal attracted much international attention.<ref>{{cite web |url= http://www.ft.com/cms/s/0/671a76ec-a950-11de-9b7f-00144feabdc0.html?catid=176&SID=google |title= The dragon stirs |publisher= [[The Financial Times]] |author= Geoff Dyer in Beijing |date = 2009-08-24 |accessdate=2009-09-18}} </ref> In a November 2009 article published in [[Foreign Affairs]] magazine, economist [[C. Fred Bergsten]] argued that Dr Zhou's suggestion or a similar change to the international monetary system would be in the United States' best interests as well as the rest of the world's.<ref name = "Bersten">{{cite web |url= http://www.foreignaffairs.com/articles/65446/c-fred-bergsten/the-dollar-and-the-deficits |title= The Dollar and the Deficits |publisher= [[Foreign Affairs]] |author= [[C. Fred Bergsten]] |date = Nov 2009 |accessdate=2009-12-15}} </ref>
Leaders meeting in April at the [[2009 G-20 London summit]] agreed to allow $250 Billion of SDRs to be created by the IMF, to be distributed to all IMF members according to each countries voting rights. In the aftermath of the summit, Gordon Brown declared "the Washington Consensus is over".<ref>{{cite news| url=http://news.sky.com/skynews/Home/Politics/Prime-Minister-Gordon-Brown-G20-Will-Pump-One-Trillion-Dollars-Into-World-Economy/Article/200904115254629| title=Prime Minister Gordon Brown: G20 Will Pump Trillion Dollars Into World Economy| date=2 April 2009| publisher=''[[Sky News]]''}}</ref> However, in a [[Keynes: The Return of the Master|book]] published during September 2009, Professor [[Robert Skidelsky]], an international expert on [[Keynesianism]], argued it was still too early to say whether a new international monetary system was emerging.<ref name = "return"/>
On Jan 27, in his opening address to the [[World Economic Forum|2010 World Economic Forum]] in Davos, President Sarkozy repeated his call for a new Bretton Woods, and was met by wild applause by a sizeable proportion of the audience.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.ft.com/cms/s/0/56dbb854-0c0b-11df-96b9-00144feabdc0.html |title=Calls for a new Bretton Woods not so mad |author = Gillian Tett |publisher=[[Financial Times]] |date=2010-01-28 |accessdate=2010-01-29 }}</ref>
In December 2011, the [[Bank of England]] published a paper arguing for reform, saying that the current International monetary system has performed poorly compared to the ''Bretton Woods system''. <ref name = "COEDec2011">{{cite web |url= http://www.bankofengland.co.uk/publications/fsr/fs_paper13.pdf |title= Reform of the International Monetary and Financial System |publisher= [[Bank of England]] |author1=Oliver Bush |author2=Katie Farrant |author3=Michelle Wright |date = 2011-12-09 |accessdate=2011-12-15}} </ref>
In August 2012 in an ''[[International Herald Tribune]]'' op-ed, Harvard University professor and director of the [[Committee on Capital Markets Regulation]] [[Hal S. Scott]] called for a global response to the [[European sovereign debt crisis|Euro-zone crisis]]. He wrote that two failures to address European problems around German power had led to world wars in the 20th century and that the current crisis was also beyond the capacity of Europe, with Germany again at the center, to solve on their own. Accepting that leadership transitions were underway in both China and America, Scott called on all concerned—with Japan included with China and America—to begin organizing a global restructuring through the [[International Monetary Fund]] with possibly a Bretton Woods II conference as part of the process. <ref>{{cite web |url= https://www.nytimes.com/2012/08/16/opinion/the-global-not-euro-zone-crisis.html |title= The Global (Not Euro-Zone) Crisis |publisher= International Herald Tribune |author= Scott, Hal S. |date = 2012-08-15 |accessdate=2012-08-16}} </ref> ''[[MarketWatch]]'' commentator Darrell Delamaide endorsed Scott's idea but concluded "unfortunately it’s not likely to happen". He added first the example of the failure of Europe to address successfully the breakup of [[Yugoslavia]] without outside assistance as a reason for his endorsement. But he found U.S. presidential and Treasury Department leadership and IMF leadership dramatically lacking in the capacity to mount an initiative such as Scott proposed. <ref>{{cite web |url= http://www.marketwatch.com/story/timid-us-imf-leaving-europe-in-the-lurch-2012-08-16 |title= Timid U.S., IMF leaving Europe in the lurch |publisher= MarketWatch |author= Delamaide, Darrell |date = 2012-08-16 |accessdate=2012-08-16}} </ref>
